'' 2 ` Not knowing what else to do , we all three returned to Constantinople to ask the advice of Sumi , and found that she was already aware of our misfortunes , having read about them in the book of Moïzes . 3 The kind-hearted creature wept bitterly at our story , but , being poor herself , could give us little help . 4 At last I proposed that every morning we should sell the silver watch into which Argentine was changed , as it would return to Sumi every evening unless it was wound up with the silver key -- which was not at all likely . 5 Sumi consented , but only on the condition that we would never sell the watch without ascertaining the house where it was to be found , so that she might also take Aurora thither , and thus Argentine would not be alone if by any chance she was wound up at the mystic hour . 6 For some weeks now we have lived by this means , and the two daughters of Siroco have never failed to return to Sumi each night . 7 Yesterday Izouf sold the silver watch to this young man , and in the evening placed the gold watch on the steps by order of Sumi , just before his customer entered the house ; from which both watches came back early this morning . ' 8 ` If I had only known ! ' 9 cried Neangir . 10 ` If I had had more presence of mind , I should have seen the lovely Argentine , and if her portrait is so fair , what must the original be ! ' 11 ` It was not your fault , ' replied the Cadi , ` you are no magician ; and who could guess that the watch must be wound at such an hour ? 12 But I shall give orders that the merchant is to hand it over to you , and this evening you will certainly not forget . ' 13 ` It is impossible to let you have it to-day , ' answered Izouf , ` for it is already sold . ' 14 ` If that is so , ' said the Cadi , ` you must return the three gold pieces which the young man paid . ' 15 The Jew , delighted to get off so easily , put his hand in his pocket , when Neangir stopped him . 16 ` No , no , ' he exclaimed , ` it is not money I want , but the adorable Argentine ; without her everything is valueless . ' 17 ` My dear Cadi , ' said the Bassa , ` he is right . 18 The treasure that my son has lost is absolutely priceless . ' 19 ` My lord , ' replied the Cadi , ` your wisdom is greater than mine . 20 Give judgment I pray you in the matter . ' 1 `` Here you are at forty-five with the roses of sixteen -- and not a gray hair , I 'll wager . '' 2 `` Blair , Blair , it is you who are always young , '' laughed Aunt Janet , not ill pleased . 3 `` Where in the world did you come from ? 4 And what is this I hear of your sleeping all night in the hammock ? '' 5 `` I 've been painting in the Lake District all summer , as you know , '' answered Uncle Blair , `` and one day I just got homesick to see my little girl . 6 So I sailed for Montreal without further delay . 7 I got here at eleven last night -- the station-master 's son drove me down . 8 Nice boy . 9 The old house was in darkness and I thought it would be a shame to rouse you all out of bed after a hard day 's work . 10 So I decided that I would spend the night in the orchard . 11 It was moonlight , you know , and moonlight in an old orchard is one of the few things left over from the Golden Age . '' 12 `` It was very foolish of you , '' said practical Aunt Janet . 13 `` These September nights are real chilly . 14 You might have caught your death of cold -- or a bad dose of rheumatism . '' 15 `` So I might . 16 No doubt it was foolish of me , '' agreed Uncle Blair gaily . 17 `` It must have been the fault , of the moonlight . 18 Moonlight , you know , Sister Janet , has an intoxicating quality . 19 It is a fine , airy , silver wine , such as fairies may drink at their revels , unharmed of it ; but when a mere mortal sips of it , it mounts straightway to his brain , to the undoing of his daylight common sense . 20 However , I have got neither cold nor rheumatism , as a sensible person would have done had he ever been lured into doing such a non-sensible thing ; there is a special Providence for us foolish folk . 1 Just then Sammy looked over to Farmer Brown 's house , and there was Farmer Brown 's boy getting ready to saw wood . 2 The imp of mischief under Sammy 's pert cap gave him an idea . 3 He flew over to the old apple-tree , just over Reddy 's head , and began to scream at the top of his lungs . 4 Farmer Brown 's boy stopped work and looked over towards the old orchard . 5 `` When a jay screams like that there is usually a fox around , '' he muttered , as he unfastened Bowser the Hound . 6 XVIII FARMER BROWN 'S BOY MAKES A DISCOVERY Reddy Fox glared up at Sammy Jay . 7 `` What 's the matter with you ? '' 8 snarled Reddy Fox . 9 `` Why do n't you mind your own affairs , instead of making trouble for other people ? '' 13 Sammy said this as if he was very much surprised to see Reddy there . 14 He was n't , for you know he had been watching Reddy hunt for Johnny Chuck 's new house , but Reddy had pretended that he was going down to the Green Meadows early that morning , and so now Sammy pretended that he had thought that Reddy really had gone . 15 `` I changed my mind ! '' 16 he snapped . 17 `` What are you screaming so for ? '' 18 `` Just to exercise my lungs , so as to be sure that I can scream when I want to , '' replied Sammy , screaming still louder . 19 `` Well , go somewhere else and scream ; I want to sleep , '' said Reddy crossly . 20 Now Sammy Jay knew perfectly well that Reddy Fox had no thought of taking a nap but was hiding there to try to catch Johnny Chuck . 1 Look at the consequences , not only to yourself , but to your two brothers , ' turning as she spoke to the men who had come in with her , and who had sunk down on the mat at the feet of the Jew . 2 The Bassa and his companions were struck both with the beauty of the Jewess and also with her words , and begged her to give them an explanation . 3 ` My lords , ' she said , ` my name is Sumi , and I am the daughter of Moïzes , one of our most famous rabbis . 4 I am the victim of my love for Izaf , ' pointing to the man who had entered last , ` and in spite of his ingratitude , I can not tear him from my heart . 5 Cruel enemy of my life , ' she continued , turning to Izaf , ` tell these gentlemen your story and that of your brothers , and try to gain your pardon by repentance . ' 6 ` We all three were born at the same time , ' said the Jew , obeying the command of Sumi at a sign from the Cadi , ` and are the sons of the famous Nathan Ben-Sadi , who gave us the names of Izif , Izouf , and Izaf . 7 From our earliest years we were taught the secrets of magic , and as we were all born under the same stars we shared the same happiness and the same troubles . 8 ` Our mother died before I can remember , and when we were fifteen our father was seized with a dangerous illness which no spells could cure . 9 Feeling death draw near , he called us to his bedside and took leave of us in these words : ' `` My sons , I have no riches to bequeath to you ; my only wealth was those secrets of magic which you know . 10 Some stones you already have , engraved with mystic signs , and long ago I taught you how to make others . 11 But you still lack the most precious of all talismans -- the three rings belonging to the daughters of Siroco . 12 Try to get possession of them , but take heed on beholding these young girls that you do not fall under the power of their beauty . 13 Their religion is different from yours , and further , they are the betrothed brides of the sons of the Bassa of the Sea . 14 And to preserve you from a love which can bring you nothing but sorrow , I counsel you in time of peril to seek out the daughter of Moïzes the Rabbi , who cherishes a hidden passion for Izaf , and possesses the Book of Spells , which her father himself wrote with the sacred ink that was used for the Talmud . '' 15 So saying , our father fell back on his cushions and died , leaving us burning with desire for the three rings of the daughters of Siroco . 16 ` No sooner were our sad duties finished than we began to make inquiries where these young ladies were to be found , and we learned after much trouble that Siroco , their father , had fought in many wars , and that his daughters , whose beauty was famous throughout all the land , were named Aurora , Argentine , and Zelida . ' 17 At the second of these names , both the Bassa and his son gave a start of surprise , but they said nothing , and Izaf went on with his story . 18 ` The first thing to be done was to put on a disguise , and it was in the dress of foreign merchants that we at length approached the young ladies , taking care to carry with us a collection of fine stones which we had hired for the occasion . 19 But alas ! 20 it was to no purpose that Nathan Ben-Sadi had warned us to close our hearts against their charms ! 1 ` If you serve me faithfully , ' returned the ogre , ` I 'll be bound you 'll get enough wages to satisfy you . ' 2 So the bargain was struck , and Antonio agreed to become the ogre 's servant . 3 He was very well treated , in every way , and he had little or no work to do , with the result that in a few days he became as fat as a quail , as round as a barrel , as red as a lobster , and as impudent as a bantam-cock . 4 But , after two years , the lad got weary of this idle life , and longed desperately to visit his home again . 5 The ogre , who could see into his heart and knew how unhappy he was , said to him one day : ` My dear Antonio , I know how much you long to see your mother and sisters again , and because I love you as the apple of my eye , I am willing to allow you to go home for a visit . 6 Therefore , take this donkey , so that you may not have to go on foot ; but see that you never say `` Bricklebrit '' to him , for if you do you 'll be sure to regret it . ' 7 Antonio took the beast without as much as saying thank you , and jumping on its back he rode away in great haste ; but he had n't gone two hundred yards when he dismounted and called out ` Bricklebrit . ' 8 No sooner had he pronounced the word than the donkey opened its mouth and poured forth rubies , emeralds , diamonds and pearls , as big as walnuts . 9 Antonio gazed in amazement at the sight of such wealth , and joyfully filling a huge sack with the precious stones , he mounted the donkey again and rode on till he came to an inn . 10 Here he got down , and going straight to the landlord , he said to him : ` My good man , I must ask you to stable this donkey for me . 11 Be sure you give the poor beast plenty of oats and hay , but beware of saying the word `` Bricklebrit '' to him , for if you do I can promise you will regret it . 12 Take this heavy sack , too , and put it carefully away for me . ' 13 The landlord , who was no fool , on receiving this strange warning , and seeing the precious stones sparkling through the canvas of the sack , was most anxious to see what would happen if he used the forbidden word . 14 So he gave Antonio an excellent dinner , with a bottle of fine old wine , and prepared a comfortable bed for him . 15 As soon as he saw the poor simpleton close his eyes and had heard his lusty snores , he hurried to the stables and said to the donkey ` Bricklebrit , ' and the animal as usual poured out any number of precious stones . 16 When the landlord saw all these treasures he longed to get possession of so valuable an animal , and determined to steal the donkey from his foolish guest . 17 As soon as it was light next morning Antonio awoke , and having rubbed his eyes and stretched himself about a hundred times he called the landlord and said to him : ` Come here , my friend , and produce your bill , for short reckonings make long friends . ' 18 When Antonio had paid his account he went to the stables and took out his donkey , as he thought , and fastening a sack of gravel , which the landlord had substituted for his precious stones , on the creature 's back , he set out for his home . 19 No sooner had he arrived there than he called out : ` Mother , come quickly , and bring table-cloths and sheets with you , and spread them out on the ground , and you will soon see what wonderful treasures I have brought you . ' 20 His mother hurried into the house , and opening the linen-chest where she kept her daughters ' wedding outfits , she took out table-cloths and sheets made of the finest linen , and spread them flat and smooth on the ground . 1 The more he thought about it , the more he tickled and laughed . 2 Right in the midst of his laughter along came Redtail the Hawk . 3 Sammy Jay opened his mouth to call to Redtail and tell him about Johnny Chuck 's secret . 4 Then he closed it again with a snap . 5 `` I wo n't tell him yet , '' said Sammy to himself , `` for he might catch one of those baby Chucks , and they are such funny little fellows that that would really be too bad . 6 I guess I 'll wait a while . '' 7 And with that , off flew Sammy Jay to hunt for some other mischief . 8 You see , he had had a change of heart . 9 The little goodness way down deep inside had come out of hiding . 10 But of course Johnny Chuck did n't know this , and over in his new house in the far corner of the old orchard , he and Polly Chuck were worrying and worrying , for they felt sure that now every one would know their secret , and it would n't be safe for the dear little baby Chucks to so much as put their funny little noses outside the door . 11 XXII JOHNNY CHUCK IS KEPT BUSY Johnny Chuck is naturally lazy . 12 You see , Johnny has very simple tastes and usually he is contented . 13 He does not have to go far from his own doorstep to get all he wants to eat . 14 He does not have to hunt for his food , as so many of the little meadow and forest people do , and so he has a great deal of time to sit on his doorstep and watch the world go by and dream pleasant daydreams and grow fat . 15 Now people who do not have to work usually become lazy . 16 It is the easiest habit in the world to learn and the hardest to get over . 17 And so , because he seldom has to work , Johnny Chuck quite naturally is lazy . 18 But Johnny can work when there really is need of it . 19 No one , unless it is Digger the Badger or Miner the Mole , can dig faster than Johnny Chuck . 20 And when there is real need of working , Johnny works with a will . 1 `` These are my little girls -- Felicity and Cecily . '' 1 But Lazarus heard of this scheme , and when the evening came , he took a log of wood , covered it with his cloak , laid it in the place where he usually slept , and then hid himself . 2 In the night the Draken came , and each one hit the log a blow with his hatchet , till it flew in pieces . 3 Then they believed their object was gained , and they lay down again . 4 Thereupon Lazarus took the log , threw it away , and laid himself down in its stead . 5 Towards dawn , he began to groan , and when the Draken heard that , they asked what ailed him , to which he made answer : ` The gnats have stung me horribly . DISAPPEARANCE OF PADDY As I remember , the spring came late that year in Carlisle . 6 It was May before the weather began to satisfy the grown-ups . 7 But we children were more easily pleased , and we thought April a splendid month because the snow all went early and left gray , firm , frozen ground for our rambles and games . 8 As the days slipped by they grew more gracious ; the hillsides began to look as if they were thinking of mayflowers ; the old orchard was washed in a bath of tingling sunshine and the sap stirred in the big trees ; by day the sky was veiled with delicate cloud drift , fine and filmy as woven mist ; in the evenings a full , low moon looked over the valleys , as pallid and holy as some aureoled saint ; a sound of laughter and dream was on the wind and the world grew young with the mirth of April breezes . 9 `` It 's so nice to be alive in the spring , '' said the Story Girl one twilight as we swung on the boughs of Uncle Stephen 's walk . 10 `` It 's nice to be alive any time , '' said Felicity , complacently . 11 `` But it 's nicer in the spring , '' insisted the Story Girl . 12 `` When I 'm dead I think I 'll FEEL dead all the rest of the year , but when spring comes I 'm sure I 'll feel like getting up and being alive again . '' 13 `` You do say such queer things , '' complained Felicity . 14 `` You wo n't be really dead any time . 15 You 'll be in the next world . 16 And I think it 's horrid to talk about people being dead anyhow . '' 17 `` We 've all got to die , '' said Sara Ray solemnly , but with a certain relish . 18 It was as if she enjoyed looking forward to something in which nothing , neither an unsympathetic mother , nor the cruel fate which had made her a colourless little nonentity , could prevent her from being the chief performer . 19 `` I sometimes think , '' said Cecily , rather wearily , `` that it is n't so dreadful to die young as I used to suppose . '' 20 She prefaced her remark with a slight cough , as she had been all too apt to do of late , for the remnants of the cold she had caught the night we were lost in the storm still clung to her . 1 `` That makes me think of another story I read the other day about Great-uncle Andrew King and Aunt Georgina , '' laughed the Story Girl . 2 `` It happened eighty years ago . 3 It was a very stormy winter and the roads were bad . 4 Uncle Andrew lived in Carlisle , and Aunt Georgina -- she was Miss Georgina Matheson then -- lived away up west , so he could n't get to see her very often . 5 They agreed to be married that winter , but Georgina could n't set the day exactly because her brother , who lived in Ontario , was coming home for a visit , and she wanted to be married while he was home . 6 So it was arranged that she was to write Uncle Andrew and tell him what day to come . 7 She did , and she told him to come on a Tuesday . 8 But her writing was n't very good and poor Uncle Andrew thought she wrote Thursday . 9 So on Thursday he drove all the way to Georgina 's home to be married . 10 It was forty miles and a bitter cold day . 11 But it was n't any colder than the reception he got from Georgina . 12 She was out in the porch , with her head tied up in a towel , picking geese . 13 She had been all ready Tuesday , and her friends and the minister were there , and the wedding supper prepared . 14 But there was no bridegroom and Georgina was furious . 15 Nothing Uncle Andrew could say would appease her . 16 She would n't listen to a word of explanation , but told him to go , and never show his nose there again . 17 So poor Uncle Andrew had to go ruefully home , hoping that she would relent later on , because he was really very much in love with her . ' 7 Every day the youth committed some fresh piece of folly , till at last Masella , losing all patience , gave him a good beating , which so startled Antonio that he took to his heels and never stopped running till it was dark and the stars were shining in the heavens . 8 He wandered on for some time , not knowing where to go , and at last he came to a cave , at the mouth of which sat an ogre , uglier than anything you can conceive . 9 He had a huge head and wrinkled brow -- eyebrows that met , squinting eyes , a flat broad nose , and a great gash of a mouth from which two huge tusks stuck out . 10 His skin was hairy , his arms enormous , his legs like sword blades , and his feet as flat as ducks ' . 11 In short , he was the most hideous and laughable object in the world . 12 But Antonio , who , with all his faults , was no coward , and was moreover a very civil-spoken lad , took off his hat , and said : ` Good-day , sir ; I hope you are pretty well . 13 Could you kindly tell me how far it is from here to the place where I wish to go ? 10 We walked the golden road and carried spring time in our hearts , and we beguiled our way with laughter and jest , and the tales the Story Girl told us -- myths and legends of elder time . 11 The walking was good , for there had lately been a thaw and everything was frozen . 12 We went over fields , crossed by spidery trails of gray fences , where the withered grasses stuck forlornly up through the snow ; we lingered for a time in a group of hill pines , great , majestic tree-creatures , friends of evening stars ; and finally struck into the belt of fir and maple which intervened between Carlisle and Baywater . 13 It was in this locality that Peg Bowen lived , and our way lay near her house though not directly in sight of it . 14 We hoped we would not meet her , for since the affair of the bewitchment of Paddy we did not know quite what to think of Peg ; the boldest of us held his breath as we passed her haunts , and drew it again with a sigh of relief when they were safely left behind . 15 The woods were full of the brooding stillness that often precedes a storm , and the wind crept along their white , cone-sprinkled floors with a low , wailing cry . 16 Around us were solitudes of snow , arcades picked out in pearl and silver , long avenues of untrodden marble whence sprang the cathedral columns of the firs . 17 We were all sorry when we were through the woods and found ourselves looking down into the snug , commonplace , farmstead-dotted settlement of Baywater . 18 `` There 's Cousin Mattie 's house -- that big white one at the turn of the road , '' said the Story Girl . 19 `` I hope she has that dinner ready , Dan . 20 I 'm hungry as a wolf after our walk . ' 1 And the day before they sailed the wedding was celebrated with magnificent rejoicings , and everybody thought that Fortunatus must certainly be a prince in disguise . 2 But when they reached Cyprus , he learned to his sorrow that both his father and mother were dead , and for some time he shut himself up in his house and would see nobody , full of shame at having forgotten them all these years . 3 Then he begged that the old man and his wife would remain with him , and take the place of his parents . 4 For twelve years Fortunatus and Cassandra and their two little boys lived happily in Famagosta . 5 They had a beautiful house and everything they could possibly want , and when Cassandra 's sisters married the purse provided them each with a fortune . 6 But at last Fortunatus grew tired of staying at home , and thought he should like to go out and see the world again . 7 Cassandra shed many tears at first when he told her of his wishes , and he had a great deal of trouble to persuade her to give her consent . 8 But on his promising to return at the end of two years she agreed to let him go . 9 Before he went away he showed her three chests of gold , which stood in a room with an iron door , and walls twelve feet thick . 10 ` If anything should happen to me , ' he said , ` and I should never come back , keep one of the chests for yourself , and give the others to our two sons . ' 11 Then he embraced them all and took ship for Alexandria . 12 The wind was fair and in a few days they entered the harbour , where Fortunatus was informed by a man whom he met on landing , that if he wished to be well received in the town , he must begin by making a handsome present to the Sultan . 13 ` That is easily done , ' said Fortunatus , and went into a goldsmith 's shop , where he bought a large gold cup , which cost five thousand pounds . 14 This gift so pleased the Sultan that he ordered a hundred casks of spices to be given to Fortunatus ; 5 If not , why did it rouse up so many old recollections , or mockeries of such , the shadows of things familiar , yet unknown , and fill my mind with confused images of her features who had spoken , though buried in the gloom of the parlor ? 6 Whom had my heart recognized , that it throbbed so ? 7 I listened , to catch her gentle breathing , and strove , by the intensity of my gaze , to picture forth a shape where none was visible . 8 Suddenly , the dry pine caught ; the fire blazed up with a ruddy glow ; and where the darkness had been , there was she , -- the Vision of the Fountain ! 9 A spirit of radiance only , she had vanished with the rainbow , and appeared again in the firelight , perhaps to flicker with the blaze , and be gone . 10 Yet , her cheek was rosy and life-like , and her features , in the bright warmth of the room , were even sweeter and tenderer than my recollection of them . 11 She knew me ! 12 The mirthful expression that had laughed in her eyes and dimpled over her countenance , when I beheld her faint beauty in the fountain , was laughing and dimpling there now . 13 One moment our glance mingled , -- the next , down rolled the heap of tan upon the kindled wood , -- and darkness snatched away that Daughter of the Light , and gave her back to me no more ! 14 Fair ladies , there is nothing more to tell . 15 Must the simple mystery be revealed , then , that Rachel was the daughter of the village squire , and had left home for a boarding-school , the morning after I arrived , and returned the day before my departure ? '' 1 Joyful sounds will ` come ringing down the wind ; ' a wealth of gypsy gold will be ours for the gathering ; we will learn the potent , unutterable charm of a dim spruce wood and the grace of flexile mountain ashes fringing a lonely glen ; we will tryst with the folk of fur and feather ; we 'll hearken to the music of gray old firs . 2 Come , and you 'll have a ramble and an afternoon that you will both remember all your lives . '' 3 We did have it ; never has its remembrance faded ; that idyllic afternoon of roving in the old Carlisle woods with the Story Girl and Uncle Blair gleams in my book of years , a page of living beauty . 4 Yet it was but a few hours of simplest pleasure ; we wandered pathlessly through the sylvan calm of those dear places which seemed that day to be full of a great friendliness ; Uncle Blair sauntered along behind us , whistling softly ; sometimes he talked to himself ; we delighted in those brief reveries of his ; Uncle Blair was the only man I have ever known who could , when he so willed , `` talk like a book , '' and do it without seeming ridiculous ; perhaps it was because he had the knack of choosing `` fit audience , though few , '' and the proper time to appeal to that audience . 5 We went across the fields , intending to skirt the woods at the back of Uncle Alec 's farm and find a lane that cut through Uncle Roger 's woods ; but before we came to it we stumbled on a sly , winding little path quite by accident -- if , indeed , there can be such a thing as accident in the woods , where I am tempted to think we are led by the Good People along such of their fairy ways as they have a mind for us to walk in . 6 `` Go to , let us explore this , '' said Uncle Blair . 7 `` It always drags terribly at my heart to go past a wood lane if I can make any excuse at all for traversing it : for it is the by-ways that lead to the heart of the woods and we must follow them if we would know the forest and be known of it . 8 When we can really feel its wild heart beating against ours its subtle life will steal into our veins and make us its own for ever , so that no matter where we go or how wide we wander in the noisy ways of cities or over the lone ways of the sea , we shall yet be drawn back to the forest to find our most enduring kinship . '' 9 `` I always feel so SATISFIED in the woods , '' said the Story Girl dreamily , as we turned in under the low-swinging fir boughs . 10 `` Trees seem such friendly things . '' 11 `` They are the most friendly things in God 's good creation , '' said Uncle Blair emphatically . 12 `` And it is so easy to live with them . 13 To hold converse with pines , to whisper secrets with the poplars , to listen to the tales of old romance that beeches have to tell , to walk in eloquent silence with self-contained firs , is to learn what real companionship is . 14 Besides , trees are the same all over the world . 15 A beech tree on the slopes of the Pyrenees is just what a beech tree here in these Carlisle woods is ; and there used to be an old pine hereabouts whose twin brother I was well acquainted with in a dell among the Apennines . 16 Listen to those squirrels , will you , chattering over yonder . 17 Did you ever hear such a fuss over nothing ? 18 Squirrels are the gossips and busybodies of the woods ; they have n't learned the fine reserve of its other denizens . 19 But after all , there is a certain shrill friendliness in their greeting . '' 7 The proposal sounded tempting , but was a little risky , and after consulting together we decided to let things remain as they were . 8 `` Do not blame me then , '' continued Thelamis , `` if you will not accept my offer . 9 But take the two pastilles , and if it ever happens that you are decapitated a second time , make use of them in the way I have shown you , and each will get back his own head . '' 10 So saying he presented us with the pastilles , and we all returned to the castle . 11 ` However , the troubles caused by the unfortunate exchange were only just beginning . 12 My head , without thinking what it was doing , led the prince 's body to my apartments . 13 But my women , only looking at the dress , declared I had mistaken the corridor , and called some slaves to conduct me to his Highness 's rooms . 14 This was bad enough , but when -- as it was still night -- my servants began to undress me , I nearly fainted from surprise and confusion , and no doubt the Prince 's head was suffering in the same manner at the other end of the castle ! 15 ` By the next morning -- you will easily guess that we slept but little -- we had grown partly accustomed to our strange situation , and when we looked in the mirror , the prince had become brown-skinned and black-haired , while my head was covered with his curly golden locks . 16 And after that first day , every one in the palace had become so accustomed to the change that they thought no more about it . 17 ` Some weeks after this , we heard that the king of the Isle of Black Marble was dead . 18 The prince 's head , which once was mine , was full of ambitious desires , and he longed to ride straight to the capital and proclaim himself king . 19 But then came the question as to whether the nobles would recognise the prince with a girl 's body , and indeed , when we came to think of it , which was prince and which was girl ? 2 I held my breath ; and it was gone ! 3 Had it passed away , or faded into nothing ? 4 I doubted whether it had ever been . 5 My sweet readers , what a dreamy and delicious hour did I spend , where that vision found and left me ! 6 For a long time I sat perfectly still , waiting till it should reappear , and fearful that the slightest motion , or even the flutter of my breath , might frighten it away . 7 Thus have I often started from a pleasant dream , and then kept quiet , in hopes to wile it back . 8 Deep were my musings , as to the race and attributes of that ethereal being . 9 Had I created her ? 10 Was she the daughter of my fancy , akin to those strange shapes which peep under the lids of children 's eyes ? 11 And did her beauty gladden me , for that one moment , and then die ? 12 Or was she a water-nymph within the fountain , or fairy , or woodland goddess peeping over my shoulder , or the ghost of some forsaken maid , who had drowned herself for love ? 13 Or , in good truth , had a lovely girl , with a warm heart , and lips that would bear pressure , stolen softly behind me , and thrown her image into the spring ? 14 I watched and waited , but no vision came again . 15 I departed , but with a spell upon me , which drew me back , that same afternoon , to the haunted spring . 16 There was the water gushing , the sand sparkling , and the sunbeam glimmering . 17 There the vision was not , but only a great frog , the hermit of that solitude , who immediately withdrew his speckled snout and made himself invisible , all except a pair of long legs , beneath a stone . 18 Methought he had a devilish look ! 17 In the middle of January , I was summoned home . 18 The day before my departure , visiting the spots which had been hallowed by the Vision , I found that the spring had a frozen bosom , and nothing but the snow and a glare of winter sunshine , on the hill of the rainbow . 19 `` Let me hope , '' thought I , `` or my heart will be as icy as the fountain , and the whole world as desolate as this snowy hill . '' 1 Uncle Blair followed her . 2 Her arms were full of Mrs. Dale 's chrysanthemums , held close up to her face , and her beautiful eyes shone softly at us over them . 3 No good-byes were said , as with roses . 10 Blossom and lyric had waited on our wishes . 11 Thoughts , careless and sweet , had visited us . 12 Laughter had been our comrade and fearless Hope our guide . 13 But now the shadow of ' 1 Cecily winced when Pat caught a mouse , visited a school chum the day the pigs were killed that she might not hear their squealing , and would not have stepped on a caterpillar for anything ; yet she did not care at all how much she made the brisk Cyrus suffer . 2 Then , suddenly , all our spring gladness and Maytime hopes were blighted as by a killing frost . 3 Sorrow and anxiety pervaded our days and embittered our dreams by night . 4 Grim tragedy held sway in our lives for the next fortnight . 5 Paddy disappeared . 6 One night he lapped his new milk as usual at Uncle Roger 's dairy door and then sat blandly on the flat stone before it , giving the world assurance of a cat , sleek sides glistening , plumy tail gracefully folded around his paws , brilliant eyes watching the stir and flicker of bare willow boughs in the twilight air above him . 7 That was the last seen of him . 8 In the morning he was not . 9 At first we were not seriously alarmed . 10 Paddy was no roving Thomas , but occasionally he vanished for a day or so . 11 But when two days passed without his return we became anxious , the third day worried us greatly , and the fourth found us distracted . 12 `` Something has happened to Pat , '' the Story Girl declared miserably . 13 `` He never stayed away from home more than two days in his life . Jacottet . 8 Paris : Leroux , éditeur . -RSB- 9 THE BEAR Once on a time there was a king who had an only daughter . 10 He was so proud and so fond of her , that he was in constant terror that something would happen to her if she went outside the palace , and thus , owing to his great love for her , he forced her to lead the life of a prisoner , shut up within her own rooms . 11 The princess did not like this at all , and one day she complained about it very bitterly to her nurse . 12 Now , the nurse was a witch , though the king did not know it . 13 For some time she listened and tried to soothe the princess ; but when she saw that she would not be comforted , she said to her : ` Your father loves you very dearly , as you know . 14 Whatever you were to ask from him he would give you . 15 The one thing he will not grant you is permission to leave the palace . 16 Now , do as I tell you . 17 Go to your father and ask him to give you a wooden wheel-barrow , and a bear 's skin . 18 When you have got them bring them to me , and I will touch them with my magic wand . 19 The wheel-barrow will then move of itself , and will take you at full speed wherever you want to go , and the bear 's skin will make such a covering for you , that no one will recognise you . ' 20 So the princess did as the witch advised her . 1 So they all determined to go on their business or pleasure , and scorned the wise advice of old Peggy . 2 Only the youngest child hesitated a minute , when she said to him , ` You stay here , my little Richard , and I will tell you beautiful stories . ' 3 But he wanted to pick a bunch of wild thyme and some blackberries by moonlight , and ran out after the others . 4 When they got outside the house they said : ` The old woman talks of wind and storm , but never was the weather finer or the sky more clear ; see how majestically the moon stalks through the transparent clouds ! '' 1 His anger hurt her with a pain she could not endure . 2 It was unbearable that Jasper should be angry with her . 3 In that moment she realized that she loved him -- that the words he had spoken when unconscious of her presence were the sweetest she had ever heard , or ever could hear . 4 Nothing mattered at all , save that he loved her and was angry with her . 5 `` Do n't say such dreadful things to me , '' she stammered , `` I did not mean to listen . 6 I could not help it . 7 I shall never laugh at you . 8 Oh , Jasper '' -- she looked bravely at him and the fine soul of her shone through the flesh like an illuminating lamp -- `` I am glad that you love me ! 9 and I am glad I chanced to overhear you , since you would never have had the courage to tell me otherwise . 10 Glad -- glad ! 11 Do you understand , Jasper ? '' 14 he said , wonderingly . 15 `` Alice -- I am so much older than you -- and they call me the Awkward Man -- they say I am unlike other people '' -- `` You ARE unlike other people , '' she said softly , `` and that is why I love you . 16 I know now that I must have loved you ever since I saw you . '' 17 `` I loved you long before I saw you , '' said Jasper . 18 He came close to her and drew her into his arms , tenderly and reverently , all his shyness and awkwardness swallowed up in the grace of his great happiness . 19 In the old garden he kissed her lips and Alice entered into her own . 20 CHAPTER XXVI . 1 I will whistle outside the gate , and when you hear me , pay no heed to what your father or mother say , leave your dancing and feasting , and come to me at once ; for if I have to leave without you , you will never find your way back alone through the forests . ' 2 When the princess was ready to start , she found that he had put on his white fur skin , and was changed back into the wolf ; and he swung her on to his back , and set out with her to her father 's palace , where he left her , while he himself returned home alone . 3 But , in the evening , he went back to fetch her , and , standing outside the palace gate , he gave a long , loud whistle . 4 In the midst of her dancing the princess heard the sound , and at once she went to him , and he swung her on his back and bore her away to his castle . 5 Again , at the end of half a year , the prince came into her room , as the white wolf , and said : ` Dear heart , you must prepare for the wedding of your second sister . 6 I will take you to your father 's palace to-day , and we will remain there together till to-morrow morning . ' 7 So they went together to the wedding . 8 In the evening , when the two were alone together , he dropped his fur skin , and , ceasing to be a wolf , became a prince again . 9 Now they did not know that the princess 's mother was hidden in the room . 10 When she saw the white skin lying on the floor , she crept out of the room , and sent a servant to fetch the skin and to burn it in the kitchen fire . 11 The moment the flames touched the skin there was a fearful clap of thunder heard , and the prince disappeared out of the palace gate in a whirlwind , and returned to his palace alone . 12 But the princess was heart-broken , and spent the night weeping bitterly . 13 Next morning she set out to find her way back to the castle , but she wandered through the woods and forests , and she could find no path or track to guide her . 14 For fourteen days she roamed in the forest , sleeping under the trees , and living upon wild berries and roots , and at last she reached a little house . 15 She opened the door and went in , and found the wind seated in the room all by himself , and she spoke to the wind and said : ` Wind , have you seen the white wolf ? ' 16 And the wind answered : ` All day and all night I have been blowing round the world , and I have only just come home ; but I have not seen him . ' 17 But he gave her a pair of shoes , in which , he told her , she would be able to walk a hundred miles with every step , Then she walked through the air till she reached a star , and she said : ` Tell me , star , have you seen the white wolf ? ' 18 And the star answered : ' I have been shining all night , and I have not seen him . '' 2 So saying , our father fell back on his cushions and died , leaving us burning with desire for the three rings of the daughters of Siroco . 3 ` No sooner were our sad duties finished than we began to make inquiries where these young ladies were to be found , and we learned after much trouble that Siroco , their father , had fought in many wars , and that his daughters , whose beauty was famous throughout all the land , were named Aurora , Argentine , and Zelida . ' 4 At the second of these names , both the Bassa and his son gave a start of surprise , but they said nothing , and Izaf went on with his story . 5 ` The first thing to be done was to put on a disguise , and it was in the dress of foreign merchants that we at length approached the young ladies , taking care to carry with us a collection of fine stones which we had hired for the occasion . 6 But alas ! 7 it was to no purpose that Nathan Ben-Sadi had warned us to close our hearts against their charms ! 8 The peerless Aurora was clothed in a garment of golden hue , studded all over with flashing jewels ; the fair-haired Argentine wore a dress of silver , and the young Zelida , loveliest of them all , the costume of a Persian lady . 9 ` Among other curiosities that we had brought with us , was a flask containing an elixir which had the quality of exciting love in the breasts of any man or woman who drank of it . 10 This had been given me by the fair Sumi , who had used it herself and was full of wrath because I refused to drink it likewise , and so return her passion . 11 I showed this liquid to the three maidens who were engaged in examining the precious stones , and choosing those that pleased them best ; and I was in the act of pouring some in a crystal cup , when Zelida 's eyes fell on a paper wrapped round the flask containing these words : `` Beware lest you drink this water with any other man than him who will one day be your husband . '' 12 `` Ah , traitor ! '' 13 she exclaimed , `` what snare have you laid for me ? '' 1 Here there reigned a king whose only daughter ran as quickly as the wind , and so lightly that she could run over a field of young oats without bending a single blade . 2 The king had given out a proclamation that anyone who could beat the princess in a race should have her for a wife , but that all who failed in the competition should lose their head . 3 As soon as Moscione heard of the Royal Proclamation , he hastened to the king and challenged the princess to race with him . 4 But on the morning appointed for the trial he sent word to the king that he was not feeling well , and that as he could not run himself he would supply someone to take his place . 5 ` It 's just the same to me , ' said Canetella , the princess ; ` let anyone come forward that likes , I am quite prepared to meet him . ' 6 At the time appointed for the race the whole place was crowded with people anxious to see the contest , and , punctual to the moment , Quick-as-Thought , and Canetella dressed in a short skirt and very lightly shod , appeared at the starting-point . 7 Then a silver trumpet sounded , and the two rivals started on their race , looking for all the world like a greyhound chasing a hare . 8 But Quick-as-Thought , true to his name , outran the princess , and when the goal was reached the people all clapped their hands and shouted , ` Long live the stranger ! ' 9 -LSB- Illustration : The Princess beaten by Quick-as-Thought -RSB- Canetella was much depressed by her defeat ; but , as the race had to be run a second time , she determined she would not be beaten again . 10 Accordingly she went home and sent Quick-as-Thought a magic ring , which prevented the person who wore it , not only from running , but even from walking , and begged that he would wear it for her sake . 11 Early next morning the crowd assembled on the race-course , and Canetella and Quick-as-Thought began their trial afresh . 12 The princess ran as quickly as ever , but poor Quick-as-Thought was like an overloaded donkey , and could not go a step . 13 Then Hit-the-Point , who had heard all about the princess 's deception from Hare 's - ear , when he saw the danger his friend was in , seized his bow and arrow and shot the stone out of the ring Quick-as-Thought was wearing . 14 In a moment the youth 's legs became free again , and in five bounds he had overtaken Canetella and won the race . 15 The king was much disgusted when he saw that he must acknowledge Moscione as his future son-in-law , and summoned the wise men of his court to ask if there was no way out of the difficulty . 16 The council at once decided that Canetella was far too dainty a morsel for the mouth of such a travelling tinker , and advised the king to offer Moscione a present of gold , which no doubt a beggar like him would prefer to all the wives in the world . 17 The king was delighted at this suggestion , and calling Moscione before him , he asked him what sum of money he would take instead of his promised bride . 18 Moscione first consulted with his friends , and then answered : ' I demand as much gold and precious stones as my followers can carry away . ' 19 The king thought he was being let off very easily , and produced coffers of gold , sacks of silver , and chests of precious stones ; but the more Strong-Back was loaded with the treasure the straighter he stood . 20 At last the treasury was quite exhausted , and the king had to send his courtiers to his subjects to collect all the gold and silver they possessed . 1 Is it so large that one head fills twelve water-tubs ? ' 10 I do n't believe it , ' said the king . 11 ` Nevertheless I am prepared to bet twelve hundred florins that it is true , ' answered the thief . 12 ` And I bet twelve hundred florins that it is a lie , ' replied the king . 13 And he straightway sent a servant into the neighbouring country to find out the truth . 14 As he rode , the servant met a man coming in the opposite direction . 15 So he hailed him and asked him where he came from . 16 And the man replied that he came out of the very town to which the man was bound . 17 Then the servant asked him if the story they had heard about the bird with the long beak was true . ' 3 They all returned to the vessel , and in a few hours the four thousand five hundred miles that lay between the island and Bagota were passed . 4 Everyone was surprised to see the change which the he also carried wooden spoons , and sold them . 2 He had a wife and one little girl , and after a long time his wife had another child . 3 The evening it was born the man went to the nearest village to fetch a nurse , and on the way he met a monk who begged him for a night 's lodging . 4 This the man willingly granted , and took him home with him . 5 There being no one far nor near to baptize the child , the man asked the monk to do him this service , and the child was given the name of Janni . 6 In the course of time Janni 's parents died , and he and his sister were left alone in the world ; soon affairs went badly with them , so they determined to wander away to seek their fortune . 7 In packing up , the sister found a knife which the monk had left for his godson , and this she gave to her brother . 8 Then they went on their way , taking with them the three sheep which were all that remained of their flocks . 9 After wandering for three days they met a man with three dogs who proposed that they should exchange animals , he taking the sheep , and they the dogs . 10 The brother and sister were quite pleased at this arrangement , and after the exchange was made they separated , and went their different ways . 11 Janni and his sister in course of time came to a great castle , in which dwelt forty Draken , who , when they heard that Janni had come , fled forty fathoms underground . 12 So Janni found the castle deserted , and abode there with his sister , and every day went out to hunt with the weapons the Draken had left in the castle . 13 One day , when he was away hunting , one of the Draken came up to get provisions , not knowing that there was anyone in the castle . 14 When he saw Janni 's sister he was terrified , but she told him not to be afraid , and by-and-by they fell in love with each other , for every time that Janni went to hunt the sister called the Drakos up . 15 Thus they went on making love to each other till at length , unknown to Janni , they got married . 16 Then , when it was too late , the sister repented , and was afraid of Janni 's wrath when he found it out . 17 One day the Drakos came to her , and said : ` You must pretend to be ill , and when Janni asks what ails you , and what you want , you must answer : `` Cherries , '' and when he inquires where these are to be found , you must say : `` There are some in a garden a day 's journey from here . '' 5 CHAPTER II . 6 A WILL , A WAY AND A WOMAN `` One day , over a hundred years ago , Ursula Townley was waiting for Kenneth MacNair in a great beechwood , where brown nuts were falling and an October wind was making the leaves dance on the ground like pixy-people . '' 7 `` What are pixy-people ? '' 8 demanded Peter , forgetting the Story Girl 's dislike of interruptions . 9 `` Hush , '' whispered Cecily . 10 `` That is only one of the Awkward Man 's poetical touches , I guess . '' 11 `` There were cultivated fields between the grove and the dark blue gulf ; but far behind and on each side were woods , for Prince Edward Island a hundred years ago was not what it is today . 12 The settlements were few and scattered , and the population so scanty that old Hugh Townley boasted that he knew every man , woman and child in it . 13 `` Old Hugh was quite a noted man in his day . 14 He was noted for several things -- he was rich , he was hospitable , he was proud , he was masterful -- and he had for daughter the handsomest young woman in Prince Edward Island . 15 `` Of course , the young men were not blind to her good looks , and she had so many lovers that all the other girls hated her -- '' `` You bet ! '' 16 said Dan , aside -- `` But the only one who found favour in her eyes was the very last man she should have pitched her fancy on , at least if old Hugh were the judge . 17 Kenneth MacNair was a dark-eyed young sea-captain of the next settlement , and it was to meet him that Ursula stole to the beechwood on that autumn day of crisp wind and ripe sunshine . 18 Old Hugh had forbidden his house to the young man , making such a scene of fury about it that even Ursula 's high spirit quailed . 19 Old Hugh had really nothing against Kenneth himself ; but years before either Kenneth or Ursula was born , Kenneth 's father had beaten Hugh Townley in a hotly contested election . 20 Political feeling ran high in those days , and old Hugh had never forgiven the MacNair his victory . 1 The servants were clearly speaking the truth , and Kristopo was obliged to believe them . 2 ` But , ' thought he , ` if they have not had a hand in this , it must be the work of the fairy , ' and in his anger he ordered the army to be ready to march . 3 On her side , Selnozoura of course knew what the genius had to expect , but was deeply offended when she heard of the base trick which she was believed to have invented . 4 Her first desire was to give battle to Kristopo at once , but with great difficulty her ministers induced her to pause , and to send an ambassador to Kristopo to try to arrange matters . 5 So the Prince Zeprady departed for the court of Ratibouf , and on his way he met Cornichon , who was encamped with his army just outside the gates of Bagota . 6 The Prince showed him the fairy 's written order that for the present peace must still be kept , and Cornichon , filled with longing to see Toupette once more , begged to be allowed to accompany Zeprady on his mission to Ratibouf . 7 By this time the genius 's passion for Toupette , which had caused all these troubles , had died out , and he willingly accepted the terms of peace offered by Zeprady , though he informed the prince that he still believed the fairy to be guilty of the dreadful change in the girl . 8 To this the prince only replied that on that point he had a witness who could prove , better than anyone else , if it was Toupette or not , and desired that Cornichon should be sent for . 9 When Toupette was told that she was to see her old lover again , her heart leapt with joy ; but soon the recollection came to her of all that had happened , and she remembered that Cornichon would be changed as well as she . 10 The moment of their meeting was not all happiness , especially on the part of Toupette , who could not forget her lost beauty , and the genius , who was present , was at last convinced that he had not been deceived , and went out to sign the treaty of peace , followed by his attendants . 11 ` Ah , Toupette : my dear Toupette ! ' 12 cried Cornichon , as soon as they were left alone ; ` now that we are once more united , let our past troubles be forgotten . ' 13 ` Our past troubles ! ' 14 answered she , ` and what do you call our lost beauty and the dreadful future before us ? 15 You are looking fifty years older than when I saw you last , and I know too well that fate has treated me no better ! ' 16 ` Ah , do not say that , ' replied Cornichon , clasping her hand , ` You are different , it is true ; but every age has its graces , and surely no woman of sixty was ever handsomer than you ! 17 If your eyes had been as bright as of yore they would have matched badly with your faded skin . 18 The wrinkles which I notice on your forehead explain the increased fulness of your cheeks , and your throat in withering is elegant in decay . 19 Thus the harmony shown by your features , even as they grow old , is the best proof of their former beauty . 20 ` Oh , monster , ' cried Toupette , bursting into tears , ` is that all the comfort you can give me ? ' 1 Then he told her who he was , and how he had seen her sisters , whose happiness was spoilt by the spell under which both their husbands lay , and she , in turn , related her story . 2 She had been carried off in the water-meadow by a horrible monster , who wanted to make her marry him by force , and had kept her a prisoner all these years because she would not submit to his will . 3 Every day he came to beg her to consent to his wishes , and to remind her that there was no hope of her being set free , as he was the most constant man in the world , and besides that he could never die . 4 At these words the youth remembered his two enchanted brothers-in-law , and he advised his sister to promise to marry the old man , if he would tell her why he could never die . 5 Suddenly everything began to tremble , as if it was shaken by a whirlwind , and the old man entered , and flinging himself at the feet of the girl , he said : ` Are you still determined never to marry me ? 6 If so you will have to sit there weeping till the end of the world , for I shall always be faithful to my wish to marry you ! ' 7 ` Well , I will marry you , ' she said , ` if you will tell me why it is that you can never die . ' 8 Then the old man burst into peals of laughter . 9 ` Ah , ah , ah ! 10 You are thinking how you would be able to kill me ? 11 Well , to do that , you would have to find an iron casket which lies at the bottom of the sea , and has a white dove inside , and then you would have to find the egg which the dove laid , and bring it here , and dash it against my head . ' 12 And he laughed again in his certainty that no one had ever got down to the bottom of the sea , and that if they did , they would never find the casket , or be able to open it . 13 When he could speak once more , he said , ` Now you will be obliged to marry me , as you know my secret . ' 14 But she begged so hard that the wedding might be put off for three days , that he consented , and went away rejoicing at his victory . 15 When he had disappeared , the brother took off the cap which had kept him invisible all this time , and told his sister not to lose heart as he hoped in three days she would be free . 16 Then he drew on his boots , and wished himself at the seashore , and there he was directly . 17 Drawing out the fish-scale , he cried , ` Come and help me , King of the Fishes ! But all the time he was storing up in his mind all these hateful things , and he meant , if ever he got free again , to make life very uncomfortable for those whose foolish tongues were trying to make ' 16 for nothing could have made her believe it possible that anyone could eclipse her . 17 But the outspoken admiration of the entire court soon undeceived her , and made her so angry that she pretended illness and retired to her own rooms , so as to avoid witnessing the princess 's triumph . 18 She also sent word to the Queen of the Flowery Isles that she was sorry not to be well enough to see her again , and advised her to return to her own states with the princess , her daughter . 19 This message was entrusted to one of the great ladies of the court , who was an old friend of the Queen of the Flowery Isles , and who advised her not to wait to take a formal leave but to go home as fast as she could . 20 The Queen was not slow to take the hint , and lost no time in obeying it . 1 Felix will edit the jokes and the Information Bureau , and Cecily must be fashion editor . 2 Yes , you must , Sis . 3 It 's easy as wink . 4 And the Story Girl will attend to the personals . 5 They 're very important . 6 Anyone can contribute a personal , but the Story Girl is to see there are some in every issue , even if she has to make them up , like Dan with the etiquette . ' 1 `` It 's ever so much worse than when he was so sick last fall , '' said Cecily drearily . 2 `` Then we knew that everything was done for him that could be done . '' 14 `` I wonder if the wishbone she gave me would have done any good , '' cried Cecily suddenly . 15 `` I 'd forgotten all about it . 16 Oh , do you suppose it 's too late yet ? '' 17 `` There 's nothing in a wishbone , '' said Dan impatiently . 18 `` You ca n't be sure . 19 She TOLD me I 'd get the wish I made on it . 20 I 'm going to try whenever I get home . '' 1 The Story Girl also got a present from the Awkward Man -- a little , shabby , worn volume with a great many marks on the leaves . 2 `` Why , it is n't new -- it 's an old book ! '' 3 exclaimed Felicity . 4 `` I did n't think the Awkward Man was mean , whatever else he was . '' 5 `` Oh , you do n't understand , Felicity , '' said the Story Girl patiently . 6 `` And I do n't suppose I can make you understand . 7 But I 'll try . 8 I 'd ten times rather have this than a new book . 9 It 's one of his own , do n't you see -- one that he has read a hundred times and loved and made a friend of . 10 A new book , just out of a shop , would n't be the same thing at all . 11 It would n't MEAN anything . 12 I consider it a great compliment that he has given me this book . 13 I 'm prouder of it than of anything else I 've got . '' 14 `` Well , you 're welcome to it , '' said Felicity . 15 `` I do n't understand and I do n't want to . 16 I would n't give anybody a Christmas present that was n't new , and I would n't thank anybody who gave me one . '' 17 Peter was in the seventh heaven because Felicity had given him a present -- and , moreover , one that she had made herself . 18 It was a bookmark of perforated cardboard , with a gorgeous red and yellow worsted goblet worked on it , and below , in green letters , the solemn warning , `` Touch Not The Cup . '' 19 As Peter was not addicted to habits of intemperance , not even to looking on dandelion wine when it was pale yellow , we did not exactly see why Felicity should have selected such a device . 20 But Peter was perfectly satisfied , so nobody cast any blight on his happiness by carping criticism . 1 Striped Chipmunk chuckled as he thought how neither of his guests knew that the other was to be there . 2 He washed his face and hands , brushed his hair , and ate his breakfast . 3 Then he scurried over to his splendid new storehouse , which no one knew of but himself , and stuffed the pockets in his cheeks with good things to eat . 4 When he could n't stuff another thing in , he scurried over to the nice , mossy log on the edge of the Green Forest , and there he emptied his pockets , for that was to be his dining table . 5 Back and forth , back and forth between his secret storehouse and the smooth , mossy log hurried Striped Chipmunk . 6 He knew that Happy Jack and the Chatterer have great appetites , and he wanted to be sure that there was plenty of good things to eat . 7 And as he scurried along , he sang a little song . 8 `` Thanksgiving comes but once a year , But when it comes it brings good cheer . 9 For in my storehouse on this day Are piles of good things hid away . 10 Each day I 've worked from early morn To gather acorns , nuts , and corn , Till now I 've plenty and to spare Without a worry or a care . 11 So light of heart the whole day long , I 'll sing a glad Thanksgiving song . '' 12 Promptly at the dinner hour Happy Jack appeared coming from one direction , and Chatterer the Red Squirrel coming from another direction . 13 They did n't see each other until just as they reached Striped Chipmunk 's smooth , mossy log . 14 Then they stopped and scowled . 15 Striped Chipmunk pretended not to notice anything wrong and bustled about , talking all the time as if his guests were the best of friends . 16 On the smooth , mossy log was a great pile of shining yellow corn . 17 There was another pile of plump ripe acorns , and three little piles of dainty looking brown seeds . 18 But the thing that Happy Jack could n't keep his eyes off was right in the middle . 19 It was a huge pile of big , fat hickory nuts . 20 Now who could remain ill-tempered and cross with such a lot of goodies spread before him ? 1 Perhaps it was because he was looking so hard for birds that he had n't seen anything else . 2 Johnny began to look , not for anything in particular , but to see everything that he could . 3 Almost right away he saw some tiny little dark spots on the water . 4 They did n't look like much of anything . 5 They were so small that he had n't noticed them before . 6 One of them was quite close to him , and as Johnny Chuck looked at it , it began to look like a tiny nose , and then -- why , just then , Johnny was very sure that one of those singing voices came right from that very spot ! 7 He was so surprised that he hopped to his feet and excitedly beckoned to Jerry Muskrat . 8 The instant he did that , the voices near him stopped singing , and the little spots on the water disappeared , leaving just the tiniest of little rings , just such tiny little rings as drops of rain falling on the Smiling Pool would make . 9 And when that tiny spot nearest to him that looked like a tiny nose disappeared , Johnny Chuck caught just a glimpse of a little form under the water . 10 `` Why -- why-e-e ! 11 The singers are Grandfather Frog 's children ! '' 12 cried Johnny Chuck . 13 `` No , they 're not , but they are own cousins to them ; they are the grandchildren of old Mr. Tree Toad ! 14 and they are called Hylas ! '' 18 said Johnny Chuck , as he started home across the Green Meadows . 19 `` I 'm glad I know who the singers of the Smiling Pool are , and I must n't forget their name -- Hylas . 20 What a funny name ! '' 9 XIX JOHNNY CHUCK 'S PRIDE Ever since Farmer Brown 's boy and Reddy Fox had found his new house in the far corner of the old orchard , Johnny Chuck had been worried . 10 It was not that he was afraid for himself . 11 Oh , my , no ! 12 Johnny Chuck felt perfectly able to take care of himself . 13 But there was Polly Chuck ! 14 He was terribly afraid that something might happen to Polly Chuck . 15 You see she was not big and strong like him , and then Polly Chuck was apt to be careless . 16 So for a while Johnny Chuck worried a great deal . 17 But Reddy Fox did n't come again in daytime . 18 You see Bowser the Hound had given him such a scare that he did n't dare to . 19 He sometimes came at night and sniffed hungrily at Johnny Chuck 's doorway , but Johnny and Polly were safe inside , and this did n't trouble them a bit . 20 And Farmer Brown 's boy seemed to have forgotten all about the new house . 1 Her eyes were very bright and excited . 2 She looked as if she had not slept a great deal . 3 She had spent the previous evening with Miss Reade and had not returned until the rest of us were in bed . 4 Miss Reade had finished giving music lessons and was going home in a few days . 5 Cecily and Felicity were in despair over this and mourned as those without comfort . 6 But the Story Girl , who had been even more devoted to Miss Reade than either of them , had not , as I noticed , expressed any regret and seemed to be very cheerful over the whole matter . 7 `` Why ca n't you tell it now ? '' 8 asked Felicity . 9 `` Because the evening is the nicest time to tell things in . 10 I only mentioned it now so that you would have something interesting to look forward to all day . '' 1 But the husband of the youngest daughter had nothing but the old broken-down horse which helped him in his garden work ; and the king , who was ashamed of this son-in-law , refused to give him any other . 2 So as he was determined not to be left behind , he went into the garden , mounted the sorry nag , and set out . 3 But scarcely had he ridden a few yards before the horse stumbled and fell . 4 So he dismounted and went down to the brook , to where the black horse lived in the vaulted hall . 5 And the horse said to him : ` Saddle and bridle me , and then go into the next room and you will find a suit of armour and a sword . 6 Put them on , and we will ride forth together to battle . ' 7 And the prince did as he was told ; and when he had mounted the horse his armour glittered in the sun , and he looked so brave and handsome , that no one would have recognised him as the gardener who swept away the dead leaves from the paths . 8 The horse bore him away at a great pace , and when they reached the battle-field they saw that the king was losing the day , so many of his warriors had been slain . 9 But when the warrior on his black charger and in glittering armour appeared on the scene , hewing right and left with his sword , the enemy were dismayed and fled in all directions , leaving the king master of the field . 10 Then the king and his two sons-in-law , when they saw their deliverer , shouted , and all that was left of the army joined in the cry : ' A god has come to our rescue ! ' 11 And they would have surrounded him , but his black horse rose in the air and bore him out of their sight . 12 Soon after this , part of the country rose in rebellion against the king , and once more he and his two sons-in-law had to fare forth to battle . 13 And the son-in-law who was disguised as a gardener wanted to fight too . 14 So he came to the king and said : ` Dear father , let me ride with you to fight your enemies . ' ' 15 I do n't want a blockhead like you to fight for me , ' answered the king . 16 ` Besides , I have n't got a horse fit for you . 17 But see , there is a carter on the road carting hay , you may take his horse . ' 18 So the prince took the carter 's horse , but the poor beast was old and tired , and after it had gone a few yards it stumbled and fell . 19 So the prince returned sadly to the garden and watched the king ride forth at the head of the army accompanied by his two sons-in-law . 20 When they were out of sight the prince betook himself to the vaulted chamber by the brook-side , and having taken counsel of the faithful black horse , he put on the glittering suit of armour , and was borne on the back of the horse through the air , to where the battle was being fought . 1 `` Never you mind Great-aunt Eliza 's nose .
