' 14 It was true ; but this fact did not seem to render the young people as miserable as it did Selnozoura . 15 ` Do not pity us , ' said Cornichon . 16 ` If we are fated to grow old so soon , let us no longer delay our marriage . 17 What matter if we anticipate our decay , if we only anticipate our happiness too ? ' 18 The fairy felt that Cornichon had reason on his side , and seeing by a glance at Toupette 's face that there was no opposition to be feared from her , she answered , ` Let it be so , then . 19 But not in this dreadful place . 20 We will return at once to Bagota , and the festivities shall be the most brilliant ever seen . ' 1 `` It happened nearly forty years ago , in October of 1851 . 2 Old Mr. Coles at the Harbour told me all about it . 3 He was a young man then and he says he can never forget that dreadful time . 4 You know in those days hundreds of American fishing schooners used to come down to the Gulf every summer to fish mackerel . 5 On one beautiful Saturday night in this October of 1851 , more than one hundred of these vessels could be counted from Markdale Capes . 6 By Monday night more than seventy of them had been destroyed . 7 Those which had escaped were mostly those which went into harbour Saturday night , to keep Sunday . 8 Mr. Coles says the rest stayed outside and fished all day Sunday , same as through the week , and HE says the storm was a judgment on them for doing it . 9 But he admits that even some of them got into harbour later on and escaped , so it 's hard to know what to think . 10 But it is certain that on Sunday night there came up a sudden and terrible storm -- the worst , Mr. Coles says , that has ever been known on the north shore . 11 It lasted for two days and scores of vessels were driven ashore and completely wrecked . 12 The crews of most of the vessels that went ashore on the sand beaches were saved , but those that struck on the rocks went to pieces and all hands were lost . 13 For weeks after the storm the north shore was strewn with the bodies of drowned men . 14 Think of it ! 15 Many of them were unknown and unrecognizable , and they were buried in Markdale graveyard . 16 Mr. Coles says the schoolmaster who was in Markdale then wrote a poem on the storm and Mr. Coles recited the first two verses to me . '' 17 ` Here are the fishers ' hillside graves , The church beside , the woods around , Below , the hollow moaning waves Where the poor fishermen were drowned . '' ' 18 A sudden tempest the blue welkin tore , The seamen tossed and torn apart Rolled with the seaweed to the shore While landsmen gazed with aching heart . ' 19 `` Mr. Coles could n't remember any more of it . 20 But the saddest of all the stories of the Yankee Storm was the one about the Franklin Dexter . 1 He had had bad dreams . 2 Ever so many times in the night he had waked up , a very unusual thing for Happy Jack . 3 The fact is , he had something on his mind . 4 Yes , Sir , Happy Jack had something on his mind , and that something was Farmer Brown 's boy . 5 He often had had Farmer Brown 's boy on his mind before , but in a very different way . 6 Then it had been in the days when Farmer Brown 's boy hunted through the Green Forest and over the Green Meadows with his terrible gun . 7 Then everybody had Farmer Brown 's boy on their minds most of the time . 8 Happy Jack had hated him then , hated him because he had feared him . 9 You know fear almost always leads to hate . 10 But now it was different . 11 Farmer Brown 's boy had put away his terrible gun . 12 Happy Jack no longer feared him . 13 Love had taken the place of hate in his heart , for had not Farmer Brown 's boy saved him from Shadow the Weasel , and brought him nuts and corn when food was scarce ? 14 And now Tommy Tit had brought word that some thing was the matter with Farmer Brown 's boy . 15 It was this that was on Happy Jack 's mind and had given him such a bad night . 16 As soon as it was daylight , Happy Jack scrambled out of bed to look for Tommy Tit . 17 He did n't have long to wait , for Tommy is quite as early a riser as Happy Jack . 18 `` Dee , dee , chickadee ! 19 I hope you feel as well as me ! '' 20 sang Tommy merrily , as he flitted over to where Happy Jack was looking for his breakfast . 1 That is why good habits are such a blessing . 2 Happy Jack Squirrel is just like the rest of us . 3 He has habits , both good and bad . 4 Of late , he had been in the habit of getting his breakfast at Farmer Brown 's house every morning , so now when he began to run from Shadow the Weasel he just naturally ran in the direction of Farmer Brown 's house from force of habit . 5 In fact , he was halfway there before he realized in which direction he was running . 6 Right then a thought came to him . 7 It gave him a wee bit of hope , and seemed to help him run just a little faster . 8 If the window of Farmer Brown 's boy 's room was open , he would run in there , and perhaps Shadow the Weasel would n't dare follow ! 9 How he did hope that that window would be open ! 10 He knew that it was his only chance . 11 He was n't quite sure that it really was a chance , for Shadow was such a bold fellow that he might not be afraid to follow him right in , but it was worth trying . 12 Along the stone wall beside the Old Orchard raced Happy Jack to the dooryard of Farmer Brown , and after him ran Shadow the Weasel , and Shadow looked as if he was enjoying himself . 13 No doubt he was . 14 He knew just as well as Happy Jack did that there was small chance of meeting Farmer Brown 's boy so early in the morning , so he felt very sure how that chase was going to end , and that when it did end he would breakfast on Squirrel . 15 By the time Happy Jack reached the dooryard , Shadow was only a few jumps behind him , and Happy Jack was pretty well out of breath . 16 He did n't stop to look to see if the way was clear . 17 There was n't time for that . 18 Besides , there could be no greater danger in front than was almost at his heels , and so , without looking one way or another , he scampered across the dooryard and up the big maple tree close to the house . 19 Shadow the Weasel was surprised . 20 He had not dreamed that Happy Jack would come over here . 1 You boys can go downstairs . 2 There 's a big pile of straw there that 'll do yez for a bed , if yez put your coats on . 3 I 'll light yez down , but I ai n't going to leave yez a light for fear yez 'd set fire to the place . '' 4 Saying good-night to the girls , who looked as if they thought their last hour was come , we went to the lower room . 5 It was quite empty , save for a pile of fire wood and another of clean straw . 6 Casting a stealthy glance around , ere Peg withdrew the light , I was relieved to see that there were no skulls in sight . 7 We four boys snuggled down in the straw . 8 We did not expect to sleep , but we were very tired and before we knew it our eyes were shut , to open no more till morning . 9 The poor girls were not so fortunate . 10 They always averred they never closed an eye . 11 Four things prevented them from sleeping . 12 In the first place Peg snored loudly ; in the second place the fitful gleams of firelight kept flickering over the skull for half the night and making gruesome effects on it ; in the third place Peg 's pillows and bedclothes smelled rankly of tobacco smoke ; and in the fourth place they were afraid the rat Peg had spoken of might come out to make their acquaintance . 13 Indeed , they were sure they heard him skirmishing about several times . 14 When we wakened in the morning the storm was over and a young morning was looking through rosy eyelids across a white world . 15 The little clearing around Peg 's cabin was heaped with dazzling drifts , and we boys fell to and shovelled out a road to her well . 16 She gave us breakfast -- stiff oatmeal porridge without milk , and a boiled egg apiece . 17 Cecily could NOT eat her porridge ; she declared she had such a bad cold that she had no appetite ; a cold she certainly had ; the rest of us choked our messes down and after we had done so Peg asked us if we had noticed a soapy taste . 18 `` The soap fell into the porridge while I was making it , '' she said . 19 `` But , '' -- smacking her lips , -- `` I 'm going to make yez an Irish stew for dinner . 20 It 'll be fine . '' 1 Fate has deprived us of our lovers , and if it depends on us the whole world shall suffer as much as we do ! ' 2 This unexpected reply was heard with amazement by all present , and the Bassa entreated the speaker to tell them her story . 3 Having obtained permission of her sister , she began : THE STORY OF THE FAIR CIRCASSIANS ` We were born in Circassia of poor people , and my sister 's name is Tezila and mine Dely . 4 Having nothing but our beauty to help us in life , we were carefully trained in all the accomplishments that give pleasure . 5 We were both quick to learn , and from our childhood could play all sorts of instruments , could sing , and above all could dance . 6 We were , besides , lively and merry , as in spite of our misfortunes we are to this day . 7 ` We were easily pleased and quite content with our lives at home , when one morning the officials who had been sent to find wives for the Sultan saw us , and were struck with our beauty . 8 We had always expected something of the sort , and were resigned to our lot , when we chanced to see two young men enter our house . 9 The elder , who was about twenty years of age , had black hair and very bright eyes . 10 The other could not have been more than fifteen , and was so fair that he might easily have passed for a girl . 11 ` They knocked at the door with a timid air and begged our parents to give them shelter , as they had lost their way . 12 After some hesitation their request was granted , and they were invited into the room in which we were . 13 And if our parents ' hearts were touched by their beauty , our own were not any harder , so that our departure for the palace , which had been arranged for the next day , suddenly became intolerable to us . 14 ` Night came , and I awoke from my sleep to find the younger of the two strangers sitting at my bedside and felt him take my hand . ' 15 `` Fear nothing , lovely Dely , '' he whispered , `` from one who never knew love till he saw you . 16 My name , '' he went on , `` is Prince Delicate , and I am the son of the King of the Isle of Black Marble . 17 My friend , who travels with me , is one of the richest nobles of my country , and the secrets which he knows are the envy of the Sultan himself . 18 And we left our native country because my father wished me to marry a lady of great beauty , but with one eye a trifle smaller than the other . '' 19 ` My vanity was flattered at so speedy a conquest , and I was charmed with the way the young man had declared his passion . 20 I turned my eyes slowly on him , and the look I gave him caused him almost to lose his senses . 1 He owned nothing but a flock of sheep , whose milk and wool he sold , and so procured himself bread to eat ; he also carried wooden spoons , and sold them . 2 He had a wife and one little girl , and after a long time his wife had another child . 3 The evening it was born the man went to the nearest village to fetch a nurse , and on the way he met a monk who begged him for a night 's lodging . 4 This the man willingly granted , and took him home with him . 5 There being no one far nor near to baptize the child , the man asked the monk to do him this service , and the child was given the name of Janni . 6 In the course of time Janni 's parents died , and he and his sister were left alone in the world ; soon affairs went badly with them , so they determined to wander away to seek their fortune . 7 In packing up , the sister found a knife which the monk had left for his godson , and this she gave to her brother . 8 Then they went on their way , taking with them the three sheep which were all that remained of their flocks . 9 After wandering for three days they met a man with three dogs who proposed that they should exchange animals , he taking the sheep , and they the dogs . 10 The brother and sister were quite pleased at this arrangement , and after the exchange was made they separated , and went their different ways . 11 Janni and his sister in course of time came to a great castle , in which dwelt forty Draken , who , when they heard that Janni had come , fled forty fathoms underground . 12 So Janni found the castle deserted , and abode there with his sister , and every day went out to hunt with the weapons the Draken had left in the castle . 13 One day , when he was away hunting , one of the Draken came up to get provisions , not knowing that there was anyone in the castle . 14 When he saw Janni 's sister he was terrified , but she told him not to be afraid , and by-and-by they fell in love with each other , for every time that Janni went to hunt the sister called the Drakos up . 15 Thus they went on making love to each other till at length , unknown to Janni , they got married . 16 Then , when it was too late , the sister repented , and was afraid of Janni 's wrath when he found it out . 17 One day the Drakos came to her , and said : ` You must pretend to be ill , and when Janni asks what ails you , and what you want , you must answer : `` Cherries , '' and when he inquires where these are to be found , you must say : `` There are some in a garden a day 's journey from here . '' 18 Then your brother will go there , and will never come back , for there dwell three of my brothers who will look after him well . ' 19 Then the sister did as the Drakos advised , and next day Janni set out to fetch the cherries , taking his three dogs with him . 20 When he came to the garden where the cherries grew he jumped off his horse , drank some water from the spring , which rose there , and fell directly into a deep sleep . 1 By this time it was nearly midnight and Neangir , who was standing near the Jewess Sumi , drew out the portrait of Argentine , and heard with delight that she was even more beautiful than her picture . 2 Every one was waiting on tiptoe for the appearance of the two watches , who were expected when the clock struck twelve to come in search of Sumi , and that there might be no delay the Bassa ordered all the doors to be flung wide open . 3 It was done , and there entered not the longed-for watches , but the page who had been sent away in disgrace . 4 Then the Bassa arose in wrath . 5 ` Azemi , ' he said , ` did I not order you to stand no more in my presence ? ' 6 ` My lord , ' replied Azemi , modestly , ' I was hidden outside the door , listening to the tale of the two Circassians . 7 And as I know you are fond of stories , give me also leave to tell you one . 8 I promise you it shall not be long . ' 9 ` Speak on , ' replied the Bassa , ` but take heed what you say . ' 10 ` My lord , ' began Azemi , ` this morning I was walking in the town when I noticed a man going in the same direction followed by a slave . 11 He entered a baker 's shop , where he bought some bread which he gave to the slave to carry . 12 I watched him and saw that he purchased many other kinds of provisions at other places , and when the slave could carry no more his master commanded him to return home and have supper ready at midnight . 13 ` When left alone the man went up the street , and turning into a jeweller 's shop , brought out a watch that as far as I could see was made of silver . 14 He walked on a few steps , then stooped and picked up a gold watch which lay at his feet . 15 At this point I ran up and told him that if he did not give me half its price I would report him to the Cadi ; he agreed , and conducting me to his house produced four hundred sequins , which he said was my share , and having got what I wanted I went away . 16 ` As it was the hour for attending on my lord I returned home and accompanied you to the Cadi , where I heard the story of the three Jews and learned the importance of the two watches I had left at the stranger 's . 17 I hastened to his house , but he had gone out , and I could only find the slave , whom I told that I was the bearer of important news for his master . 18 Believing me to be one of his friends , he begged me to wait , and showed me into a room where I saw the two watches lying on the table . 19 I put them in my pocket , leaving the four hundred sequins in place of the gold watch and three gold pieces which I knew to be the price of the other . 20 As you know the watches never remain with the person who buys them , this man may think himself very lucky to get back his money . 1 `` You can tell her all about it , '' comforted Felix . 2 `` Telling is n't a bit like talking it over , '' retorted Cecily . 3 `` It 's too one-sided . '' 4 We had an exciting time opening our presents . 5 Some of us had more than others , but we all received enough to make us feel comfortably that we were not unduly neglected in the matter . 6 The contents of the box which the Story Girl 's father had sent her from Paris made our eyes stick out . 7 It was full of beautiful things , among them another red silk dress -- not the bright , flame-hued tint of her old one , but a rich , dark crimson , with the most distracting flounces and bows and ruffles ; and with it were little red satin slippers with gold buckles , and heels that made Aunt Janet hold up her hands in horror . 8 Felicity remarked scornfully that she would have thought the Story Girl would get tired wearing red so much , and even Cecily commented apart to me that she thought when you got so many things all at once you did n't appreciate them as much as when you only got a few . 9 `` I 'd never get tired of red , '' said the Story Girl . 10 `` I just love it -- it 's so rich and glowing . 11 When I 'm dressed in red I always feel ever so much cleverer than in any other colour . 12 Thoughts just crowd into my brain one after the other . 13 Oh , you darling dress -- you dear , sheeny , red-rosy , glistening , silky thing ! Fortunatus put them on board his ship , and commanded the captain to return to Cyprus and deliver them to his wife , Cassandra . 10 He next obtained an audience of the Sultan , and begged permission to travel through the country , which the Sultan readily gave him , adding some letters to the rulers of other lands which Fortunatus might wish to visit . 11 Filled with delight at feeling himself free to roam through the world once more , Fortunatus set out on his journey without losing a day . 12 From court to court he went , astonishing everyone by the magnificence of his dress and the splendour of his presents . 13 At length he grew as tired of wandering as he had been of staying at home , and returned to Alexandria , where he found the same ship that had brought him from Cyprus lying in the harbour . 14 Of course the first thing he did was to pay his respects to the Sultan , who was eager to hear about his adventures . 15 When Fortunatus had told them all , the Sultan observed : ` Well , you have seen many wonderful things , but I have something to show you more wonderful still ; ' 1 II JOHNNY CHUCK RECEIVES CALLERS The morning after gentle Sister South Wind arrived on the Green Meadows , Peter Rabbit came hopping and skipping down the Lone Little Path from the Green Forest . 2 Peter was happy . 3 He did n't know why . 4 He just was happy . 5 It was in the air . 6 Everybody else seemed happy , too . 7 Peter had to stop every few minutes just to kick up his heels and try to jump over his own shadow . 8 He had felt just that way ever since gentle Sister South Wind arrived . 9 `` I simply have to kick and dance ! 10 I can not help but gaily prance ! 11 Somehow I feel it in my toes Whenever gentle South Wind blows . 13 The quicker that you do your work The longer time you 'll have to play . '' 14 Johnny never has forgotten this , and when it is really necessary that he should work , no one works harder than he does . 15 But he always first makes sure that it is necessary work and that he will not be wasting his time in doing foolish , unnecessary things . 16 And now Johnny Chuck was the busiest he had ever been in all his life . 17 If he felt lazy these beautiful spring days , he did n't have time to think about it . 18 No , Sir , he actually did n't have time to remember that he is naturally lazy . 19 You see , he had a family to look out for -- three babies to find sweet , tender young clover for and to teach all the things that every Chuck should know , and to watch out for , that no harm should come to them . 20 So Johnny Chuck was busy , so busy that he hardly had time to get enough to eat . 1 Had I ever heard that sweet , low tone ? 2 If not , why did it rouse up so many old recollections , or mockeries of such , the shadows of things familiar , yet unknown , and fill my mind with confused images of her features who had spoken , though buried in the gloom of the parlor ? 3 Whom had my heart recognized , that it throbbed so ? 4 I listened , to catch her gentle breathing , and strove , by the intensity of my gaze , to picture forth a shape where none was visible . 5 Suddenly , the dry pine caught ; the fire blazed up with a ruddy glow ; and where the darkness had been , there was she , -- the Vision of the Fountain ! 6 A spirit of radiance only , she had vanished with the rainbow , and appeared again in the firelight , perhaps to flicker with the blaze , and be gone . 7 Yet , her cheek was rosy and life-like , and her features , in the bright warmth of the room , were even sweeter and tenderer than my recollection of them . 8 She knew me ! 9 The mirthful expression that had laughed in her eyes and dimpled over her countenance , when I beheld her faint beauty in the fountain , was laughing and dimpling there now . 10 One moment our glance mingled , -- the next , down rolled the heap of tan upon the kindled wood , -- and darkness snatched away that Daughter of the Light , and gave her back to me no more ! 11 Fair ladies , there is nothing more to tell . 12 Must the simple mystery be revealed , then , that Rachel was the daughter of the village squire , and had left home for a boarding-school , the morning after I arrived , and returned the day before my departure ? 9 It is called love . 10 XII JOHNNY CHUCK PROVES HIS LOVE These spring days were beautiful days on the Green Meadows . 11 It seemed to Johnny Chuck that the Green Meadows never had been so lovely or the songs of the birds so sweet . 12 He had forgotten all about his old friends , Jimmy Skunk and Peter Rabbit and the other little meadow people . 13 You see , he could n't think of anybody but Polly Chuck , and he did n't want to be with anybody but Polly Chuck . 14 He had even forgotten that he had started out to see the world . 15 He did n't care anything more about the world . 16 All he wanted was to be where Polly Chuck was . 17 Then he was perfectly happy . 18 That was because Johnny Chuck had found the greatest thing in the world , which is love . 19 But Johnny still had one great wish , the wish that he might show Polly Chuck just how brave and strong he was and how well he could take care of her . 20 One morning they were feasting in a patch of sweet clover over near an old stone wall . 1 She reached the house , oiled the hinges of the door , threw the loaf to the dog , gave the poor woman at the well the rope , and the woman in the kitchen the broom , caught up the casket from the top of the cupboard , and fled with it out of the house . 2 But the witch heard her as she ran away , and rushing to the window called out to the woman in the kitchen : ` Kill that thief , I tell you ! '' 16 said Dan , aside -- `` But the only one who found favour in her eyes was the very last man she should have pitched her fancy on , at least if old Hugh were the judge . 17 Kenneth MacNair was a dark-eyed young sea-captain of the next settlement , and it was to meet him that Ursula stole to the beechwood on that autumn day of crisp wind and ripe sunshine . 18 Old Hugh had forbidden his house to the young man , making such a scene of fury about it that even Ursula 's high spirit quailed . 19 Old Hugh had really nothing against Kenneth himself ; but years before either Kenneth or Ursula was born , Kenneth 's father had beaten Hugh Townley in a hotly contested election . 20 Political feeling ran high in those days , and old Hugh had never forgiven the MacNair his victory . 1 He agreed to accompany Fortunatus back to Cyprus , but only on condition he should first be allowed to return for a few weeks to his own home before venturing to set sail for an island so strange and distant . 2 Fortunatus agreed to his proposal , and as he was always fond of anything new , said that he would go with him . 3 The journey was long , and they had to cross many large rivers , and climb over high mountains , and find their way through thick woods , before they reached at length the old man 's castle . 4 His wife and children had almost given up hopes of seeing him again , and crowded eagerly round him . 5 Indeed , it did not take Fortunatus five minutes to fall in love with the youngest daughter , the most beautiful creature in the whole world , whose name was Cassandra . 6 ` Give her to me for my wife , ' he said to the old man , ` and let us all go together to Famagosta . ' 7 So a ship was bought big enough to hold Fortunatus , the old man and his wife , and their ten children -- five of them sons and five daughters . 8 And the day before they sailed the wedding was celebrated with magnificent rejoicings , and everybody thought that Fortunatus must certainly be a prince in disguise . 9 But when they reached Cyprus , he learned to his sorrow that both his father and mother were dead , and for some time he shut himself up in his house and would see nobody , full of shame at having forgotten them all these years . 10 Then he begged that the old man and his wife would remain with him , and take the place of his parents . 11 For twelve years Fortunatus and Cassandra and their two little boys lived happily in Famagosta . 12 They had a beautiful house and everything they could possibly want , and when Cassandra 's sisters married the purse provided them each with a fortune . 13 But at last Fortunatus grew tired of staying at home , and thought he should like to go out and see the world again . 14 Cassandra shed many tears at first when he told her of his wishes , and he had a great deal of trouble to persuade her to give her consent . 15 But on his promising to return at the end of two years she agreed to let him go . 16 Before he went away he showed her three chests of gold , which stood in a room with an iron door , and walls twelve feet thick . 17 ` If anything should happen to me , ' he said , ` and I should never come back , keep one of the chests for yourself , and give the others to our two sons . ' 18 Then he embraced them all and took ship for Alexandria . 19 The wind was fair and in a few days they entered the harbour , where Fortunatus was informed by a man whom he met on landing , that if he wished to be well received in the town , he must begin by making a handsome present to the Sultan . 20 ` That is easily done , ' said Fortunatus , and went into a goldsmith 's shop , where he bought a large gold cup , which cost five thousand pounds . 1 `` Who were Ursula Townley and Kenneth MacNair ? ' 10 ` We all three were born at the same time , ' said the Jew , obeying the command of Sumi at a sign from the Cadi , ` and are the sons of the famous Nathan Ben-Sadi , who gave us the names of Izif , Izouf , and Izaf . 11 From our earliest years we were taught the secrets of magic , and as we were all born under the same stars we shared the same happiness and the same troubles . 12 ` Our mother died before I can remember , and when we were fifteen our father was seized with a dangerous illness which no spells could cure . 13 Feeling death draw near , he called us to his bedside and took leave of us in these words : ' `` My sons , I have no riches to bequeath to you ; my only wealth was those secrets of magic which you know . 14 Some stones you already have , engraved with mystic signs , and long ago I taught you how to make others . 15 But you still lack the most precious of all talismans -- the three rings belonging to the daughters of Siroco . 16 Try to get possession of them , but take heed on beholding these young girls that you do not fall under the power of their beauty . 17 Their religion is different from yours , and further , they are the betrothed brides of the sons of the Bassa of the Sea . 18 And to preserve you from a love which can bring you nothing but sorrow , I counsel you in time of peril to seek out the daughter of Moïzes the Rabbi , who cherishes a hidden passion for Izaf , and possesses the Book of Spells , which her father himself wrote with the sacred ink that was used for the Talmud . '' 19 So saying , our father fell back on his cushions and died , leaving us burning with desire for the three rings of the daughters of Siroco . 20 ` No sooner were our sad duties finished than we began to make inquiries where these young ladies were to be found , and we learned after much trouble that Siroco , their father , had fought in many wars , and that his daughters , whose beauty was famous throughout all the land , were named Aurora , Argentine , and Zelida . ' 1 To accomplish this we used all our arts and very soon bent them to our wills , so that they could refuse us nothing . 2 At the end of the day we remained possessors of the talismans and had left them to their fate , while the Prince and Thelamis fell more in love with us than ever , and declared that we were more lovely than any women in the world . 3 ` The sun had set before we quitted the inn , and we had made no plans as to where we should go next , so we readily consented to the prince 's proposal that we should embark without delay for the Isle of Black Marble . 4 What a place it was ! 5 Rocks blacker than jet towered above its shores and shed thick darkness over the country . 6 Our sailors had not been there before and were nearly as frightened as ourselves , but thanks to Thelamis , who undertook to be our pilot , we landed safely on the beach . 7 ` When we had left the coast behind us , with its walls of jet , we entered a lovely country where the fields were greener , the streams clearer , and the sun brighter than anywhere else . 8 The people crowded round to welcome their prince , whom they loved dearly , but they told him that the king was still full of rage at his son 's refusal to marry his cousin the Princess Okimpare , and also at his flight . 9 Indeed , they all begged him not to visit the capital , as his life would hardly be safe . 10 So , much as I should have enjoyed seeing the home of my beloved prince , I implored him to listen to this wise advice and to let us all go to Thelamis 's palace in the middle of a vast forest . 11 ` To my sister and myself , who had been brought up in a cottage , this house of Thelamis 's seemed like fairyland . 12 It was built of pink marble , so highly polished that the flowers and streams surrounding it were reflected as in a mirror . 13 One set of rooms was furnished especially for me in yellow silk and silver , to suit my black hair . 14 Fresh dresses were provided for us every day , and we had slaves to wait on us . 15 Ah , why could not this happiness have lasted for ever ! ' 8 He was very rich and powerful , and had everything in the world he could desire except a child . 9 But at last , after he had been married for many years , and was quite an old man , his wife Renzolla presented him with a fine daughter , whom they called Cannetella . 10 She grew up into a beautiful girl , and was as tall and straight as a young fir-tree . 11 When she was eighteen years old her father called her to him and said : ` You are of an age now , my daughter , to marry and settle down ; but as I love you more than anything else in the world , and desire nothing but your happiness , I am determined to leave the choice of a husband to yourself . 12 Choose a man after your own heart , and you are sure to satisfy me . ' 13 Cannetella thanked her father very much for his kindness and consideration , but told him that she had not the slightest wish to marry , and was quite determined to remain single . 14 The king , who felt himself growing old and feeble , and longed to see an heir to the throne before he died , was very unhappy at her words , and begged her earnestly not to disappoint him . 15 When Cannetella saw that the king had set his heart on her marriage , she said : ` Very well , dear father , I will marry to please you , for I do not wish to appear ungrateful for all your love and kindness ; but you must find me a husband handsomer , cleverer , and more charming than anyone else in the world . ' 16 The king was overjoyed by her words , and from early in the morning till late at night he sat at the window and looked carefully at all the passers-by , in the hopes of finding a son-in-law among them . 17 One day , seeing a very good-looking man crossing the street , the king called his daughter and said : ` Come quickly , dear Cannetella , and look at this man , for I think he might suit you as a husband . ' 7 When the Cadi was informed of what had taken place he ordered the crowd to be dispersed by blows , after the Turkish manner , and then asked Neangir to state his complaint . 8 After hearing the young man 's story , which seemed to him most extraordinary , he turned to question the Jewish merchant , who instead of answering raised his eyes to heaven and fell down in a dead faint . 9 The judge took no notice of the swooning man , but told Neangir that his tale was so singular he really could not believe it , and that he should have the merchant carried back to his own house . 10 This so enraged Neangir that he forgot the respect due to the Cadi , and exclaimed at the top of his voice , ` Recover this fellow from his fainting fit , and force him to confess the truth , ' giving the Jew as he spoke a blow with his sword which caused him to utter a piercing scream . 11 ` You see for yourself , ' said the Jew to the Cadi , ` that this young man is out of his mind . 12 I forgive him his blow , but do not , I pray you , leave me in his power . ' 13 At that moment the Bassa chanced to pass the Cadi 's house , and hearing a great noise , entered to inquire the cause . 14 When the matter was explained , he looked attentively at Neangir , and asked him gently how all these marvels could possibly have happened . 15 ` My lord , ' replied Neangir , ' I swear I have spoken the truth , and perhaps you will believe me when I tell you that I myself have been the victim of spells wrought by people of this kind , who should be rooted out from the earth . 16 For three years I was changed into a three-legged pot , and only returned to man 's shape when one day a turban was laid upon my lid . ' 17 At these words the Bassa rent his robe for joy , and embracing Neangir , he cried , ` Oh , my son , my son , have I found you at last ? 18 Do you not come from the house of Mohammed and Zinebi ? ' 19 ` Yes , my lord , ' replied Neangir , ` it was they who took care of me during my misfortune , and taught me by their example to be less worthy of belonging to you . ' 20 ` Blessed be the Prophet , ' said the Bassa , ` who has restored one of my sons to me , at the time I least expected it ! 1 `` If you -- would care -- to read it -- you may have it , '' Jasper contrived to say . 2 She carried the book away with her . 3 He did not again hide when she passed , and when she brought the book back they talked a little about it over the fence . 4 He lent her others , and got some from her in return ; they fell into the habit of discussing them . 5 Jasper did not find it hard to talk to her now ; it seemed as if he were talking to his dream Alice , and it came strangely natural to him . 6 He did not talk volubly , but Alice thought what he did say was worth while . 7 His words lingered in her memory and made music . 8 She always found his flowers under the pine , and she always wore some of them , but she did not know if he noticed this or not . 9 One evening Jasper walked shyly with her from his gate up the pine hill . 10 After that he always walked that far with her . 11 She would have missed him much if he had failed to do so ; '' 3 and the Story Girl was wont to render it with such dramatic intensity and power that the veriest dullard among her listeners could not have missed its force and significance . 4 She swept along through the poem royally , playing on the emotions of her audience as she had so often played on ours in the old orchard . 5 Pity , terror , indignation , suspense , possessed her hearers in turn . 6 In the court scene she surpassed herself . 7 She was , in very truth , the Florentine judge , stern , stately , impassive . 8 Her voice dropped into the solemnity of the all-important line , '' ` The court pronounces the defendant -- ' '' She paused for a breathless moment , the better to bring out the tragic import of the last word . 9 `` DEAD , '' piped up Sara Ray in her shrill , plaintive little voice . 10 The effect , to use a hackneyed but convenient phrase , can better be imagined than described . 11 Instead of the sigh of relieved tension that should have swept over the audience at the conclusion of the line , a burst of laughter greeted it . 12 The Story Girl 's performance was completely spoiled . 13 She dealt the luckless Sara a glance that would have slain her on the spot could glances kill , stumbled lamely and impotently through the few remaining lines of her recitation , and fled with crimson cheeks to hide her mortification in the little corner that had been curtained off for a dressing-room . 14 Mr. Perkins looked things not lawful to be uttered , and the audience tittered at intervals for the rest of the performance . 15 Sara Ray alone remained serenely satisfied until the close of the concert , when we surrounded her with a whirlwind of reproaches . 16 `` Why , '' she stammered aghast , `` what did I do ? 17 I -- I thought she was stuck and that I ought to prompt her quick . ' 4 -LSB- Illustration : The Princess beaten by Quick-as-Thought -RSB- Canetella was much depressed by her defeat ; but , as the race had to be run a second time , she determined she would not be beaten again . 5 Accordingly she went home and sent Quick-as-Thought a magic ring , which prevented the person who wore it , not only from running , but even from walking , and begged that he would wear it for her sake . 6 Early next morning the crowd assembled on the race-course , and Canetella and Quick-as-Thought began their trial afresh . 7 The princess ran as quickly as ever , but poor Quick-as-Thought was like an overloaded donkey , and could not go a step . 8 Then Hit-the-Point , who had heard all about the princess 's deception from Hare 's - ear , when he saw the danger his friend was in , seized his bow and arrow and shot the stone out of the ring Quick-as-Thought was wearing . 9 In a moment the youth 's legs became free again , and in five bounds he had overtaken Canetella and won the race . 10 The king was much disgusted when he saw that he must acknowledge Moscione as his future son-in-law , and summoned the wise men of his court to ask if there was no way out of the difficulty . 11 The council at once decided that Canetella was far too dainty a morsel for the mouth of such a travelling tinker , and advised the king to offer Moscione a present of gold , which no doubt a beggar like him would prefer to all the wives in the world . 12 The king was delighted at this suggestion , and calling Moscione before him , he asked him what sum of money he would take instead of his promised bride . 13 Moscione first consulted with his friends , and then answered : ' I demand as much gold and precious stones as my followers can carry away . ' 14 The king thought he was being let off very easily , and produced coffers of gold , sacks of silver , and chests of precious stones ; but the more Strong-Back was loaded with the treasure the straighter he stood . 15 At last the treasury was quite exhausted , and the king had to send his courtiers to his subjects to collect all the gold and silver they possessed . 16 But nothing was of any avail , and Strong-Back only asked for more . 17 When the king 's counsellors saw the unexpected result of their advice , they said it would be more than foolish to let some strolling thieves take so much treasure out of the country , and urged the king to send a troop of soldiers after them , to recover the gold and precious stones . 18 So the king sent a body of armed men on foot and horse , to take back the treasure Strong-Back was carrying away with him . 19 But Hare 's - ear , who had heard what the counsellors had advised the king , told his companions just as the dust of their pursuers was visible on the horizon . 20 No sooner had Blow-Blast taken in their danger than he raised such a mighty wind that all the king 's army was blown down like so many nine-pins , and as they were quite unable to get up again , Moscione and his companions proceeded on their way without further let or hindrance . 1 Then he plumped down beside it , took off his hat , wiped his face , and settled back to listen to the sermon , just as if it was all a matter of course . 2 When the service was over he hoisted his bag up again , marched out of church , and drove home . 3 He could never understand why it made so much talk ; but he was known by the name of Oatmeal Frewen for years . for his food , as so many of the little meadow and forest people do , and so he has a great deal of time to sit on his doorstep and watch the world go by and dream pleasant daydreams and grow fat . 7 Now people who do not have to work usually become lazy . 8 It is the easiest habit in the world to learn and the hardest to get over . 9 And so , because he seldom has to work , Johnny Chuck quite naturally is lazy . 10 But Johnny can work when there really is need of it . 11 No one , unless it is Digger the Badger or Miner the Mole , can dig faster than Johnny Chuck . 12 And when there is real need of working , Johnny works with a will . 13 When he was a very tiny Chuck , old Mother Chuck had taught him this : `` When work there is that must be done Do n't fret and whine and spoil the day ! 14 The quicker that you do your work The longer time you 'll have to play . '' 15 Johnny never has forgotten this , and when it is really necessary that he should work , no one works harder than he does . 16 But he always first makes sure that it is necessary work and that he will not be wasting his time in doing foolish , unnecessary things . 17 And now Johnny Chuck was the busiest he had ever been in all his life . 18 If he felt lazy these beautiful spring days , he did n't have time to think about it . 19 No , Sir , he actually did n't have time to remember that he is naturally lazy . 20 You see , he had a family to look out for -- three babies to find sweet , tender young clover for and to teach all the things that every Chuck should know , and to watch out for , that no harm should come to them . 1 When they had finished their well , they held a council as to who should be made the guardian of the well , so that the jackal might not come near it , for , they said , ` he would not work , therefore he shall not drink . ' 1 Dear me , dear me , Johnny Chuck certainly did have his hands full , teaching those three little Chucks to mind ! 2 They were such lively little chaps , and there was so much that was new and wonderful to see , that it was dreadfully hard work to sit perfectly still , just because Johnny Chuck told them to . 3 But if they did n't mind instantly , they were sure to have their ears soundly boxed , and sometimes were sent back to the house without a taste of the sweet , tender , young clover of which they were so fond . 4 After a few lessons of this kind , they found out that it was always best to obey instantly , and then Johnny began to teach them other things , things which it is very important that every Chuck should know . 5 First , there were signals . 6 When Johnny whistled a certain way , it meant `` A stranger in sight ; possible danger ! the sun had declined behind a birch on a distant hill and it seemed a tree with a blazing heart of fire . 10 The great golden willow at the lane gate was laughter-shaken in the wind of evening . 11 Even amid all the changes of our shifting world we could not be hopelessly low-spirited -- except Sara Ray , who was often so , and Peter , who was rarely so . 12 But Peter had been sorely vexed in spirit for several days . 13 The time was approaching for the October issue of Our Magazine and he had no genuine fiction ready for it . 14 He had taken so much to heart Felicity 's taunt that his stories were all true that he had determined to have a really-truly false one in the next number . 15 But the difficulty was to get anyone to write it . 16 He had asked the Story Girl to do it , but she refused ; then he appealed to me and I shirked . 17 Finally Peter determined to write a story himself . 18 `` It ought n't to be any harder than writing a poem and I managed that , '' he said dolefully . 19 He worked at it in the evenings in the granary loft , and the rest of us forebore to question him concerning it , because he evidently disliked talking about his literary efforts . 20 But this evening I had to ask him if he would soon have it ready , as I wanted to make up the paper . 1 Peg 's voice rose almost to a shriek . 2 We were dreadfully frightened , for we knew there were times when she was quite crazy and we feared one of her `` spells '' was coming on her . 3 But with a swift movement she turned the man 's coat she wore up over her shoulders and head like a hood , completely hiding her face . 4 Then she crouched forward , elbows on knees , and relapsed into silence . 5 None of us dared speak or move . 6 We sat thus for half an hour . 7 Then Peg jumped up and said briskly in her usual tone , `` Well , I guess yez are all sleepy and ready for bed . 8 You girls can sleep in my bed over there , and I 'll take the sofy . 9 Yez can put the cat off if yez like , though he wo n't hurt yez . 10 You boys can go downstairs . 11 There 's a big pile of straw there that 'll do yez for a bed , if yez put your coats on . 12 I 'll light yez down , but I ai n't going to leave yez a light for fear yez 'd set fire to the place . '' 13 Saying good-night to the girls , who looked as if they thought their last hour was come , we went to the lower room . 14 It was quite empty , save for a pile of fire wood and another of clean straw . 15 Casting a stealthy glance around , ere Peg withdrew the light , I was relieved to see that there were no skulls in sight . 16 We four boys snuggled down in the straw . 17 We did not expect to sleep , but we were very tired and before we knew it our eyes were shut , to open no more till morning . 18 The poor girls were not so fortunate . 19 They always averred they never closed an eye . 20 Four things prevented them from sleeping . 1 But my hair will look like dried hay tonight . ' 1 At length , one morning , they saw from the windows that the fairy and the genius were approaching , in state , with all their courtiers in attendance . 2 Toupette instantly hid herself in the darkest corner of the room , but Cornichon , forgetting that he was now no longer a boy of fourteen , ran to meet them . 3 In so doing he tripped and fell , bruising one of his eyes severely . 4 At the sight of her lover lying helpless on the floor , Toupette hastened to his side ; but her feeble legs gave way under her , and she fell almost on top of him , knocking out three of her loosened teeth against his forehead . 5 The fairy , who entered the room at this moment , burst into tears , and listened in silence to the genius , who hinted that by-and-by everything would be put right . 6 ` At the last assembly of the fairies , ' he said , ` when the doings of each fairy were examined and discussed , a proposal was made to lessen , as far as possible , the mischief caused by Dindonette by enchanting the fountain . 7 And it was decided that , as she had meant nothing but kindness , she should have the power of undoing one half of the spell . 8 Of course she might always have destroyed the fatal fountain , which would have been best of all ; but this she never thought of . 9 Yet , in spite of this , her heart is so good , that I am sure that the moment she hears that she is wanted she will fly to help . 10 Only , before she comes , it is for you , Madam , to make up your mind which of the two shall regain their former strength and beauty . 11 Why Golden Milestone , when Pinewood or Hillslope or , if you wanted to be very fanciful , Ivy Lodge , might be had for the taking ? 12 He had lived alone at Golden Milestone since his mother 's death ; he had been twenty then and he was close upon forty now , though he did not look it . 13 But neither could it be said that he looked young ; he had never at any time looked young with common youth ; there had always been something in his appearance that stamped him as different from the ordinary run of men , and , apart from his shyness , built up an intangible , invisible barrier between him and his kind . 14 He had lived all his life in Carlisle ; and all the Carlisle people knew of or about him -- although they thought they knew everything -- was that he was painfully , abnormally shy . 15 He never went anywhere except to church ; he never took part in Carlisle 's simple social life ; even with most men he was distant and reserved ; as for women , he never spoke to or looked at them ; if one spoke to him , even if she were a matronly old mother in Israel , he was at once in an agony of painful blushes . 16 He had no friends in the sense of companions ; to all outward appearance his life was solitary and devoid of any human interest . 17 He had no housekeeper ; but his old house , furnished as it had been in his mother 's lifetime , was cleanly and daintily kept . 18 The quaint rooms were as free from dust and disorder as a woman could have had them . 19 This was known , because Jasper Dale occasionally had his hired man 's wife , Mrs. Griggs , in to scrub for him . 20 On the morning she was expected he betook himself to woods and fields , returning only at night-fall . 1 He does n't believe in missions at all -- in fact , he says he detests the very mention of missions -- and he never gives one cent to them . '' 1 The day before , just about noon , she had suddenly felt the magic power over her disappear , and ever since that moment she had eagerly awaited the arrival of her deliverers . 2 She went on to say that there was yet another princess shut up in the castle , who had also fallen under the might of the magician . 3 They wandered through many halls and rooms till at last they found the second princess , who was quite as grateful as the first , and thanked the three companions most warmly for having set her free . 4 Then the princesses told their rescuers that a great treasure lay hidden in the cellars of the castle , but that it was carefully guarded by a fierce and terrible dog . 5 Nothing daunted , they all went down below at once , and found the fierce animal mounting guard over the treasure as the princesses had said . 6 But one blow from the blacksmith 's hammer soon made an end of the monster , and they found themselves in a vaulted chamber full of gold and silver and precious stones . 7 Beside the treasure stood a young and handsome man , who advanced to meet them , and thanked the nun , the blacksmith , and the countryman , for having freed him from the magic spell he was under . 8 He told them that he was a king 's son , who had been banished to this castle by a wicked magician , and that he had been changed into the three-headed dwarf . 9 When he had lost two of his heads the magic power over the two princesses had been removed , and when the blacksmith had killed the horrible dog , then he too had been set free . 10 To show his gratitude he begged the three companions to divide the treasure between them , which they did ; but there was so much of it that it took a very long time . 11 The princesses , too , were so grateful to their rescuers , that one married the blacksmith , and the other the countryman . 12 Then the prince claimed the nun as his bride , and they all lived happily together till they died . 13 -LSB- From the German , Kletke . -RSB- 14 HERR LAZARUS AND THE DRAKEN Once upon a time there was a cobbler called Lazarus , who was very fond of honey . 15 One day , as he ate some while he sat at work , the flies collected in such numbers that with one blow he killed forty . 16 Then he went and ordered a sword to be made for him , on which he had written these words : ` With one blow I have slain forty . ' 17 When the sword was ready he took it and went out into the world , and when he was two days ' journey from home he came to a spring , by which he laid himself down and slept . 18 Now in that country there dwelt Draken , one of whom came to the spring to draw water ; there he found Lazarus sleeping , and read what was written on his sword . 19 Then he went back to his people and told them what he had seen , and they all advised him to make fellowship with this powerful stranger . 20 So the Draken returned to the spring , awoke Lazarus , and said that if it was agreeable to him they should make fellowship together . 1 Happy Jack . 2 Striped Chipmunk sat on a mossy old log , laughing until his sides ached . 3 `` Ha , ha , ha ! 4 Ho , ho , ho ! 5 Oh , dear ! 6 Oh , dear ! 7 Ho , ho , ho , ho , ho ! ' 1 The queen began at once : ' I have been much surprised by your behaviour to Mutinosa ; she had insulted our whole race , and deserved punishment . 2 You might forgive your own wrongs if you chose , but not those of others . 3 You treated her very gently whilst she was with you , and I come now to avenge our wrongs on her daughter . 4 You have ensured her being lovely and clever , and not subject to change of form , but I shall place her in an enchanted prison , which she shall never leave till she finds herself in the arms of a lover whom she herself loves . 5 It will be my care to prevent anything of the kind happening . ' 6 The enchanted prison was a large high tower in the midst of the sea , built of shells of all shapes and colours . 7 The lower floor was like a great bathroom , where the water was let in or off at will . 8 The first floor contained the princess 's apartments , beautifully furnished . 9 On the second was a library , a large wardrobe-room filled with beautiful clothes and every kind of linen , a music room , a pantry with bins full of the best wines , and a store-room with all manner of preserves , bonbons , pastry and cakes , all of which remained as fresh as if just out of the oven . 10 The top of the tower was laid out like a garden , with beds of the loveliest flowers , fine fruit trees , and shady arbours and shrubs , where many birds sang amongst the branches . 11 The fairies escorted Graziella and her governess , Bonnetta , to the tower , and then mounted a dolphin which was waiting for them . 12 At a little distance from the tower the queen waved her wand and summoned two thousand great fierce sharks , whom she ordered to keep close guard , and not to let a soul enter the tower . 13 The good governess took such pains with Graziella 's education that when she was nearly grown up she was not only most accomplished , but a very sweet , good girl . 14 One day , as the princess was standing on a balcony , she saw the most extraordinary figure rise out of the sea . 15 She quickly called Bonnetta to ask her what it could be . 16 It looked like some kind of man , with a bluish face and long sea-green hair . 17 He was swimming towards the tower , but the sharks took no notice of him . 18 ` It must be a merman , ' said Bonnetta . '' 9 As the writing proceeded we scholars exploded into smothered laughter , despite our awe of Mr. Perkins . 10 Mr. Perkins himself could not keep a straight face . 11 He turned abruptly away and looked out of the window , but we could see his shoulders shaking . 12 When Cecily had finished and had thrown down the chalk with bitter vehemence , he turned around with a very red face . 13 `` That will do . 14 You may sit down . 15 Cyrus , since it seems you are the guilty person , take the eraser and wipe that off the board . 16 Then go stand in the corner , facing the room , and hold your arms straight above your head until I tell you to take them down . '' 4 he said to her and me , one idle afternoon of opal skies , pied meadows and misty hills . 5 It was Saturday and Peter had gone home ; Felix and Dan were helping Uncle Alec top turnips ; Cecily and Felicity were making cookies for Sunday , so the Story Girl and I were alone in Uncle Stephen 's Walk . 6 We liked to be alone together that last month , to think the long , long thoughts of youth and talk about our futures . 7 There had grown up between us that summer a bond of sympathy that did not exist between us and the others . 8 We were older than they -- the Story Girl was fifteen and I was nearly that ; and all at once it seemed as if we were immeasurably older than the rest , and possessed of dreams and visions and forward-reaching hopes which they could not possibly share or understand . 9 At times we were still children , still interested in childish things . 10 But there came hours when we seemed to our two selves very grown up and old , and in those hours we talked our dreams and visions and hopes , vague and splendid , as all such are , over together , and so began to build up , out of the rainbow fragments of our childhood 's companionship , that rare and beautiful friendship which was to last all our lives , enriching and enstarring them . 11 For there is no bond more lasting than that formed by the mutual confidences of that magic time when youth is slipping from the sheath of childhood and beginning to wonder what lies for it beyond those misty hills that bound the golden road . 12 `` Where are you going ? '' 5 CHAPTER XII . 6 FLOWERS O ' MAY Accordingly we went a-maying , following the lure of dancing winds to a certain westward sloping hill lying under the spirit-like blue of spring skies , feathered over with lisping young pines and firs , which cupped little hollows and corners where the sunshine got in and never got out again , but stayed there and grew mellow , coaxing dear things to bloom long before they would dream of waking up elsewhere . 7 'T was there we found our mayflowers , after faithful seeking . 8 Mayflowers , you must know , never flaunt themselves ; they must be sought as becomes them , and then they will yield up their treasures to the seeker -- clusters of star-white and dawn-pink that have in them the very soul of all the springs that ever were , re-incarnated in something it seems gross to call perfume , so exquisite and spiritual is it . 9 We wandered gaily over the hill , calling to each other with laughter and jest , getting parted and delightfully lost in that little pathless wilderness , and finding each other unexpectedly in nooks and dips and sunny silences , where the wind purred and gentled and went softly . 10 When the sun began to hang low , sending great fan-like streamers of radiance up to the zenith , we foregathered in a tiny , sequestered valley , full of young green fern , lying in the shadow of a wooded hill . 11 In it was a shallow pool -- a glimmering green sheet of water on whose banks nymphs might dance as blithely as ever they did on Argive hill or in Cretan dale . 12 There we sat and stripped the faded leaves and stems from our spoil , making up the blossoms into bouquets to fill our baskets with sweetness . 13 The Story Girl twisted a spray of divinest pink in her brown curls , and told us an old legend of a beautiful Indian maiden who died of a broken heart when the first snows of winter were falling , because she believed her long-absent lover was false . 14 But he came back in the spring time from his long captivity ; and when he heard that she was dead he sought her grave to mourn her , and lo , under the dead leaves of the old year he found sweet sprays of a blossom never seen before , and knew that it was a message of love and remembrance from his dark-eyed sweet-heart . 15 `` Except in stories Indian girls are called squaws , '' remarked practical Dan , tying his mayflowers together in one huge , solid , cabbage-like bunch . 16 Not for Dan the bother of filling his basket with the loose sprays , mingled with feathery elephant 's - ears and trails of creeping spruce , as the rest of us , following the Story Girl 's example , did . 17 Nor would he admit that ours looked any better than his . 18 `` I like things of one kind together . 19 I do n't like them mixed , '' he said . 20 `` You have no taste , '' said Felicity . 1 Dee , dee , good for you ! '' 1 CHAPTER XXXIII SAMMY JAY UPSETS HAPPY JACK A good deed well done often is overlooked , but you never are allowed to forget a mistake . 2 Happy Jack . 3 Sammy Jay chuckled as he flew across the snow-covered Green Meadows on his way to his home in the Green Forest . 4 He chuckled and he chuckled . 5 To have heard him you would have thought that either he had thought of something very pleasant , or something very pleasant had happened to him . 6 Once he turned in the direction of Farmer Brown 's house , but changed his mind as he saw the Black Shadows creeping out from the Purple Hills , and once more headed for the Green Forest . 7 `` Too late to-day . 8 Time I was home now . 9 It 'll keep until to-morrow , '' he muttered . 10 Then he chuckled , and he was still chuckling when he reached the big hemlock tree , among the thick branches of which he spent each night . 11 `` Do n't know what started me off to the Old Pasture this afternoon , but I 'm glad I went . 12 My , my , my , but I 'm glad I went , '' said he , as he fluffed out his feathers and prepared to tuck his head under his wing . 13 `` It pays to snoop around in this world and see what is going on . 14 I learned a long time ago not to believe everything I hear , and that the surest way to make sure of things is to find out for myself . 15 Nothing like using my own eyes and my own ears . 16 Well , I must get to sleep . '' 17 He began to chuckle again , and he was still chuckling as he fell asleep . 18 The next morning Sammy Jay was astir at the very first sign of light . 19 He waited just long enough to see that every feather was in place , for Sammy is a bit vain , and very particular about his dress . 20 Then he headed straight for Farmer Brown 's house . 1 He had no housekeeper ; but his old house , furnished as it had been in his mother 's lifetime , was cleanly and daintily kept . 2 The quaint rooms were as free from dust and disorder as a woman could have had them . 3 This was known , because Jasper Dale occasionally had his hired man 's wife , Mrs. Griggs , in to scrub for him . 4 On the morning she was expected he betook himself to woods and fields , returning only at night-fall . 5 During his absence Mrs. Griggs was frankly wont to explore the house from cellar to attic , and her report of its condition was always the same -- `` neat as wax . '' 1 Having nothing but our beauty to help us in life , we were carefully trained in all the accomplishments that give pleasure . 2 We were both quick to learn , and from our childhood could play all sorts of instruments , could sing , and above all could dance . 3 We were , besides , lively and merry , as in spite of our misfortunes we are to this day . 4 ` We were easily pleased and quite content with our lives at home , when one morning the officials who had been sent to find wives for the Sultan saw us , and were struck with our beauty . 5 We had always expected something of the sort , and were resigned to our lot , when we chanced to see two young men enter our house . 6 The elder , who was about twenty years of age , had black hair and very bright eyes . 7 The other could not have been more than fifteen , and was so fair that he might easily have passed for a girl . 8 ` They knocked at the door with a timid air and begged our parents to give them shelter , as they had lost their way . 9 After some hesitation their request was granted , and they were invited into the room in which we were . 10 And if our parents ' hearts were touched by their beauty , our own were not any harder , so that our departure for the palace , which had been arranged for the next day , suddenly became intolerable to us . 11 ` Night came , and I awoke from my sleep to find the younger of the two strangers sitting at my bedside and felt him take my hand . 5 Well , he hardly knew himself . 6 He had slept comfortably all the long winter . 7 He had awakened very , very hungry , but now he had plenty to eat . 8 All about him the birds were singing or busily at work building new homes . 9 And still Johnny Chuck felt unhappy . 10 It was dreadful to feel this way and not have any good reason for it . 11 One bright morning Johnny Chuck sat on his door-step watching Drummer the Woodpecker building a new home in the old apple-tree . 12 Drummer 's red head flew back and forth , back and forth , and his sharp bill cut out tiny bits of wood . 13 It was slow work ; it was hard work . 14 But Drummer seemed happy , very happy indeed . 15 It was watching Drummer that started Johnny Chuck to thinking about his own home . 16 He had always thought it a very nice home . 17 He had built it just as he wanted it . 18 From the doorstep he could look in all directions over the Green Meadows . 19 It had a front door and a hidden back door . 20 Yes , it was a very nice home indeed . 1 On the smooth , mossy log was a great pile of shining yellow corn . 2 There was another pile of plump ripe acorns , and three little piles of dainty looking brown seeds . 3 But the thing that Happy Jack could n't keep his eyes off was right in the middle . 4 It was a huge pile of big , fat hickory nuts . 5 Now who could remain ill-tempered and cross with such a lot of goodies spread before him ? 6 Certainly not Happy Jack or his cousin , Chatterer the Red Squirrel . 7 They just had to smile in spite of themselves , and when Striped Chipmunk urged them to sit down and help themselves , they did . 8 In three minutes they were so busy eating that they had forgotten all about their quarrel and were laughing and chatting like the best of friends . 9 `` It 's quite a family party , is n't it ? '' 10 said Striped Chipmunk , for you know they are all cousins . 11 Whitefoot the Wood Mouse happened along , and Striped Chipmunk insisted that he should join the party . 12 Later Sammy Jay came along , and nothing would excuse him from sharing in the feast , too . 13 When everybody had eaten and eaten until they could n't hold another thing , and it was time to think of going home , Striped Chipmunk insisted that Happy Jack and Chatterer should divide between them the big , fat hickory nuts that were left , and they did without once quarreling about it . 14 `` Thanksgiving comes but once a year , And when it comes it brings good cheer , '' said Striped Chipmunk to himself as he watched his guests depart . 15 CHAPTER XII HAPPY JACK DOES SOME THINKING To call another a thief does n't make him one . 16 Happy Jack . 17 Happy Jack sat up in a chestnut tree , and his face was very sober . 18 The fact is , Happy Jack was doing some very hard thinking . 19 This is so very unusual for him that Sammy Jay stopped to ask if he was sick . 20 You see he is naturally a happy-go-lucky little scamp , and that is one reason that he is called Happy Jack . 1 It took him some time to make up his mind to go , but finally he did . 2 This time when they reached the tree close by the house , they found a great surprise awaiting them . 3 Farmer Brown 's boy was sitting just inside the window , looking out . 4 At least , they thought it was Farmer Brown 's boy , but when they got a little nearer , they grew doubtful . 5 It looked like Farmer Brown 's boy , and yet it did n't . 6 His cheeks stuck way out just as Striped Chipmunk 's do when he has them stuffed full of corn or nuts . 7 Happy Jack stared at him very hard . 8 `` My goodness , I did n't know he carried his food that way ! '' 9 he exclaimed . 10 `` I should think it would be dreadfully uncomfortable . ' 20 Then he let her tie his fingers together with a thread , and immediately he became powerless . 1 It was a very simple little story , that of the slender brown reed which grew by the forest pool and always was sad and sighing because it could not utter music like the brook and the birds and the winds . 2 All the bright , beautiful things around it mocked it and laughed at it for its folly . 3 Who would ever look for music in it , a plain , brown , unbeautiful thing ? 4 But one day a youth came through the wood ; he was as beautiful as the spring ; he cut the brown reed and fashioned it according to his liking ; and then he put it to his lips and breathed on it ; and , oh , the music that floated through the forest ! 5 It was so entrancing that everything -- brooks and birds and winds -- grew silent to listen to it . 6 Never had anything so lovely been heard ; it was the music that had for so long been shut up in the soul of the sighing reed and was set free at last through its pain and suffering . 7 I had heard the Story Girl tell many a more dramatic tale ; but that one stands out for me in memory above them all , partly , perhaps , because of the spot in which she told it , partly because it was the last one I was to hear her tell for many years -- the last one she was ever to tell me on the golden road . 8 When Uncle Blair had finished his sketch the shafts of sunshine were turning crimson and growing more and more remote ; the early autumn twilight was falling over the woods . 9 We left our dell , saying good-bye to it for ever , as the Story Girl had suggested , and we went slowly homeward through the fir woods , where a haunting , indescribable odour stole out to meet us . 10 `` There is magic in the scent of dying fir , '' Uncle Blair was saying aloud to himself , as if forgetting he was not quite alone . 11 `` It gets into our blood like some rare , subtly-compounded wine , and thrills us with unutterable sweetnesses , as of recollections from some other fairer life , lived in some happier star . 12 Compared to it , all other scents seem heavy and earth-born , luring to the valleys instead of the heights . 13 But the tang of the fir summons onward and upward to some ` far-off , divine event ' -- some spiritual peak of attainment whence we shall see with unfaltering , unclouded vision the spires of some aerial City Beautiful , or the fulfilment of some fair , fadeless land of promise . '' 1 You see , Happy Jack was spying on Striped Chipmunk . 2 Yes , Sir , Happy Jack was spying . 3 Spying , you know , is secretly watching other people and trying to find out what they are doing . 4 It is n't a nice thing to do , not a bit nice . 5 Happy Jack knew it , and all the time he was doing it , he was feeling very much ashamed of himself . 6 But he said to himself that he just had to know where Striped Chipmunk 's storehouse was , because he just had to peep inside and find out if it held any of the big , fat hickory nuts that had disappeared from under the tall hickory tree while he was quarreling up in the top of it with his cousin , Chatterer the Red Squirrel . 7 But spying on Striped Chipmunk is n't the easiest thing in the world . 8 Happy Jack was finding it the hardest work he had ever undertaken . 9 Striped Chipmunk is so spry , and whisks about so , that you need eyes all around your head to keep track of him . 10 Happy Jack found that his two eyes , bright and quick as they are , could n't keep that little elf of a cousin of his always in sight . 11 Every few minutes he would disappear and then bob up again in the most unexpected place and most provoking way . 12 `` Now I 'm here , and now I 'm there ! 13 Now I am not anywhere ! 14 Watch me now , for here I go Out of sight ! 15 I told you so ! '' 1 But neither could it be said that he looked young ; he had never at any time looked young with common youth ; there had always been something in his appearance that stamped him as different from the ordinary run of men , and , apart from his shyness , built up an intangible , invisible barrier between him and his kind . 2 He had lived all his life in Carlisle ; and all the Carlisle people knew of or about him -- although they thought they knew everything -- was that he was painfully , abnormally shy . 3 He never went anywhere except to church ; he never took part in Carlisle 's simple social life ; even with most men he was distant and reserved ; as for women , he never spoke to or looked at them ; if one spoke to him , even if she were a matronly old mother in Israel , he was at once in an agony of painful blushes . 4 He had no friends in the sense of companions ; to all outward appearance his life was solitary and devoid of any human interest . 5 He had no housekeeper ; but his old house , furnished as it had been in his mother 's lifetime , was cleanly and daintily kept . 6 The quaint rooms were as free from dust and disorder as a woman could have had them . 7 This was known , because Jasper Dale occasionally had his hired man 's wife , Mrs. Griggs , in to scrub for him . 8 On the morning she was expected he betook himself to woods and fields , returning only at night-fall . 9 During his absence Mrs. Griggs was frankly wont to explore the house from cellar to attic , and her report of its condition was always the same -- `` neat as wax . that is , most of the little meadow people did . 11 Peter Rabbit did n't . 12 Peter used to stop every day to gossip with Johnny Chuck and tell him all the news , and now that Johnny Chuck was no longer there , Peter missed him greatly . 13 Jimmy Skunk was always asleep or off somewhere . 14 Besides , he was such a traveler that he knew all the news almost as soon as Peter himself . 15 The Merry Little Breezes told Peter that Johnny Chuck was still on the Green Meadows , hunting for a new home , so Peter made up his mind that just as soon as Johnny got settled , Peter would hunt him up and call . 16 You see , he never dreamed that Johnny would leave the Green Meadows , and he thought that of course the Merry Little Breezes would tell him just where Johnny Chuck 's new house was , whenever it was built . 17 But there is where Peter made a mistake . 18 The Merry Little Breezes are the friends of all the little meadow and forest people , but they would n't be very long if they told everything that they find out . 19 Their merry tongues they guard full well And things they should n't never tell , For long ago they learned the way To keep a secret night and day . 20 And so when they found Johnny Chuck 's new house in the corner of Farmer Brown 's old orchard , they promised Johnny that they would n't tell anybody , and they did n't . 1 `` There were cultivated fields between the grove and the dark blue gulf ; but far behind and on each side were woods , for Prince Edward Island a hundred years ago was not what it is today . 2 The settlements were few and scattered , and the population so scanty that old Hugh Townley boasted that he knew every man , woman and child in it . 3 `` Old Hugh was quite a noted man in his day . 4 He was noted for several things -- he was rich , he was hospitable , he was proud , he was masterful -- and he had for daughter the handsomest young woman in Prince Edward Island . 5 `` Of course , the young men were not blind to her good looks , and she had so many lovers that all the other girls hated her -- '' `` You bet ! '' 12 `` Was the MacNair a Conservative or a Grit ? ' 5 ` It is God 's will , ' answered the fisherman 's wife . 6 ` Nay , my child , it is not God 's will , but the fault of your husband ; for if he would but catch the little gold-fish you would surely have children . 7 To-night , when he comes home , tell him he must go back and catch the little fish . 8 He must then cut it in six pieces -- one of these you must eat , and your husband the second , and soon after you will have two children . 9 The third piece you must give to the dog , and she will have two puppies . 10 The fourth piece give to the mare , and she will have two foals . 11 The fifth piece bury on the right of the house door , and the sixth on the left , and two cypress trees will spring up there . ' 12 When the fisherman came home at evening his wife told him all that the old woman had advised , and he promised to bring home the little gold-fish . 13 Next morning , therefore , he went very early to the water , and caught the little fish . 14 Then they did as the old woman had ordered , and in due time the fisherman 's wife had two sons , so like each other that no one could tell the difference . 15 The dog had two puppies exactly alike , the mare had two foals , and on each side of the front door there sprang up two cypress trees precisely similar . 16 When the two boys were grown up , they were not content to remain at home , though they had wealth in plenty ; but they wished to go out into the world , and make a name for themselves . 17 Their father would not allow them both to go at once , as they were the only children he had . 18 He said : ` First one shall travel , and when he is come back then the other may go . ' 19 So the one took his horse and his dog , and went , saying to his brother : ` So long as the cypress trees are green , that is a sign that I am alive and well ; but if one begins to wither , then make haste and come to me .
