3 But one day a youth came through the wood ; he was as beautiful as the spring ; he cut the brown reed and fashioned it according to his liking ; and then he put it to his lips and breathed on it ; and , oh , the music that floated through the forest ! 4 It was so entrancing that everything -- brooks and birds and winds -- grew silent to listen to it . 5 Never had anything so lovely been heard ; it was the music that had for so long been shut up in the soul of the sighing reed and was set free at last through its pain and suffering . 6 I had heard the Story Girl tell many a more dramatic tale ; but that one stands out for me in memory above them all , partly , perhaps , because of the spot in which she told it , partly because it was the last one I was to hear her tell for many years -- the last one she was ever to tell me on the golden road . 7 When Uncle Blair had finished his sketch the shafts of sunshine were turning crimson and growing more and more remote ; the early autumn twilight was falling over the woods . 8 We left our dell , saying good-bye to it for ever , as the Story Girl had suggested , and we went slowly homeward through the fir woods , where a haunting , indescribable odour stole out to meet us . 9 `` There is magic in the scent of dying fir , '' Uncle Blair was saying aloud to himself , as if forgetting he was not quite alone . 10 `` It gets into our blood like some rare , subtly-compounded wine , and thrills us with unutterable sweetnesses , as of recollections from some other fairer life , lived in some happier star . 11 Compared to it , all other scents seem heavy and earth-born , luring to the valleys instead of the heights . 12 But the tang of the fir summons onward and upward to some ` far-off , divine event ' -- some spiritual peak of attainment whence we shall see with unfaltering , unclouded vision the spires of some aerial City Beautiful , or the fulfilment of some fair , fadeless land of promise . thoughtless , he was not bad-hearted . 11 As soon as their existence crossed his mind , he set about making preparations to visit them , and as he was not fond of being alone he looked round for some '' 6 Then each little Chuck would sit up very straight and not move the teeniest , weeniest bit , so that from a little distance they looked for all the world like tiny stumps . 7 But all the time their sharp little eyes would be looking this way and that way , to see what the danger might be . 8 After a while Johnny would give another little whistle , which meant `` Danger past . '' 9 Then they would once more begin to fill their little stomachs with sweet , tender , young clover . 10 Sometimes , however , Johnny would whistle sharply . 11 That meant `` Run ! '' 12 Then they would scamper as fast as they could along the nearest little path to the house under the old apple-tree in the far corner , and never once look around . 13 They would dive head first , one after the other , in at the doorway , and not show their noses outside again until Johnny or Polly Chuck told them they could . 14 Then there was a still different whistle . 15 It meant `` Danger very near ; lie low ! ' 19 for nothing could have made her believe it possible that anyone could eclipse her . 20 But the outspoken admiration of the entire court soon undeceived her , and made her so angry that she pretended illness and retired to her own rooms , so as to avoid witnessing the princess 's triumph . 1 `` Is it possible ? '' 1 It is the year 's carnival ere the dull Lenten days of leafless valleys and penitential mists come . 2 The time of apple-picking had come around once more and we worked joyously . 3 Uncle Blair picked apples with us , and between him and the Story Girl it was an October never to be forgotten . 4 `` Will you go far afield for a walk with me to-day ? '' 5 he said to her and me , one idle afternoon of opal skies , pied meadows and misty hills . 6 It was Saturday and Peter had gone home ; Felix and Dan were helping Uncle Alec top turnips ; Cecily and Felicity were making cookies for Sunday , so the Story Girl and I were alone in Uncle Stephen 's Walk . 7 We liked to be alone together that last month , to think the long , long thoughts of youth and talk about our futures . 8 There had grown up between us that summer a bond of sympathy that did not exist between us and the others . 9 We were older than they -- the Story Girl was fifteen and I was nearly that ; and all at once it seemed as if we were immeasurably older than the rest , and possessed of dreams and visions and forward-reaching hopes which they could not possibly share or understand . 10 At times we were still children , still interested in childish things . 11 But there came hours when we seemed to our two selves very grown up and old , and in those hours we talked our dreams and visions and hopes , vague and splendid , as all such are , over together , and so began to build up , out of the rainbow fragments of our childhood 's companionship , that rare and beautiful friendship which was to last all our lives , enriching and enstarring them . 12 For there is no bond more lasting than that formed by the mutual confidences of that magic time when youth is slipping from the sheath of childhood and beginning to wonder what lies for it beyond those misty hills that bound the golden road . 13 `` Where are you going ? '' 14 asked the Story Girl . 15 `` To ` the woods that belt the gray hillside ' -- ay , and overflow beyond it into many a valley purple-folded in immemorial peace , '' answered Uncle Blair . 16 `` I have a fancy for one more ramble in Prince Edward Island woods before I leave Canada again . 17 But I would not go alone . 18 So come , you two gay youthful things to whom all life is yet fair and good , and we will seek the path to Arcady . 19 There will be many little things along our way to make us glad . 20 Joyful sounds will ` come ringing down the wind ; ' a wealth of gypsy gold will be ours for the gathering ; we will learn the potent , unutterable charm of a dim spruce wood and the grace of flexile mountain ashes fringing a lonely glen ; we will tryst with the folk of fur and feather ; we 'll hearken to the music of gray old firs . 1 she cried . 2 Johnny looked ruefully at the hole he had worked so hard to dig ; then he brushed the dirt from his clothes and followed her . 3 This time Johnny had no fault to find with the ground . 4 It was high and dry . 5 But Polly had chosen a spot close to a road that wound down across the Green Meadows . 6 Johnny shook his head doubtfully , but he began to dig . 7 This time , however , he kept one eye on Polly Chuck , and the minute he found that she was wandering off , he stopped digging and chuckled as he watched her . 8 It was n't long before back she came in great excitement . 9 She had found a better place ! 10 So they wandered over the Green Meadows , Polly leading the way . 11 Johnny had learned by this time to waste no time digging . 12 And he had made up his mind to one thing . 13 What do you think it was ? 14 It was this : He would follow Polly until she found a place to suit him , but when she did find such a place she should n't have a chance to change her mind again . 15 XIV A NEW HOME AT LAST Home , no matter where it be , Or it be big or small , Is just the one place in the world That dearest is of all . 16 Johnny Chuck was thinking of this as he worked with might and main . 17 It was a new house that he was building , but already he felt that it was home , and every time he thought of it he felt a queer little tugging at his heart . 18 You see , while it was his home , it was Polly Chuck 's home , too , and that made it doubly dear to Johnny Chuck , even before it was finished . 19 And where do you think Johnny was building his new home ? ' 18 ` Seeing is believing , ' returned the cautious Moscione . 19 Blow-Blast at once began to convince him of the truth of his assertion . 20 First he blew so softly that it seemed like the gentle breeze at evening , and then he turned round and raised such a mighty storm , that he blew down a whole row of oak trees . 1 When he woke he said to himself , ` The maiden did a good deed when she told me where to find water . 2 A few hours more , and I should have been dead . 3 So I will do her bidding , and seek out her native town and the man for whom the message was given . ' 16 So the bargain was struck , and Antonio agreed to become the ogre 's servant . 17 He was very well treated , in every way , and he had little or no work to do , with the result that in a few days he became as fat as a quail , as round as a barrel , as red as a lobster , and as impudent as a bantam-cock . 18 But , after two years , the lad got weary of this idle life , and longed desperately to visit his home again . 19 The ogre , who could see into his heart and knew how unhappy he was , said to him one day : ` My dear Antonio , I know how much you long to see your mother and sisters again , and because I love you as the apple of my eye , I am willing to allow you to go home for a visit . 20 Therefore , take this donkey , so that you may not have to go on foot ; but see that you never say `` Bricklebrit '' to him , for if you do you 'll be sure to regret it . '' 8 Saying good-night to the girls , who looked as if they thought their last hour was come , we went to the lower room . 9 It was quite empty , save for a pile of fire wood and another of clean straw . 10 Casting a stealthy glance around , ere Peg withdrew the light , I was relieved to see that there were no skulls in sight . 11 We four boys snuggled down in the straw . 12 We did not expect to sleep , but we were very tired and before we knew it our eyes were shut , to open no more till morning . 13 The poor girls were not so fortunate . 14 They always averred they never closed an eye . 15 Four things prevented them from sleeping . 16 In the first place Peg snored loudly ; in the second place the fitful gleams of firelight kept flickering over the skull for half the night and making gruesome effects on it ; in the third place Peg 's pillows and bedclothes smelled rankly of tobacco smoke ; and in the fourth place they were afraid the rat Peg had spoken of might come out to make their acquaintance . 17 Indeed , they were sure they heard him skirmishing about several times . 18 When we wakened in the morning the storm was over and a young morning was looking through rosy eyelids across a white world . 19 The little clearing around Peg 's cabin was heaped with dazzling drifts , and we boys fell to and shovelled out a road to her well . 20 She gave us breakfast -- stiff oatmeal porridge without milk , and a boiled egg apiece . 1 `` I am sure I shall , '' said Alice Dale , turning to her husband . 2 He looked down into her eyes -- and we were quite forgotten by both of them . 3 We saw it , and slipped away , while Jasper Dale drew his wife into their home and shut the world out . 4 We scampered joyously away through the moonlit dusk . 5 Uncle Blair joined us at the gate and the Story Girl asked him what he thought of the bride . 6 `` When she dies white violets will grow out of her dust , '' he answered . 7 `` Uncle Blair says even queerer things than the Story Girl , '' Felicity whispered to me . 8 And so that beautiful day went away from us , slipping through our fingers as we tried to hold it . 9 It hooded itself in shadows and fared forth on the road that is lighted by the white stars of evening . 10 It had been a gift of Paradise . 11 Its hours had all been fair and beloved . 12 From dawn flush to fall of night there had been naught to mar it . 13 It took with it its smiles and laughter . 14 But it left the boon of memory . 15 CHAPTER XXVII . 16 THE OLD ORDER CHANGETH `` I am going away with father when he goes . 17 He is going to spend the winter in Paris , and I am to go to school there . '' 3 CHAPTER XVIII HAPPY JACK DECIDES TO MAKE A CALL You 'll find when all is said and done Two heads are better far than one . 4 Happy Jack . 5 Happy Jack Squirrel had n't slept very well . 6 He had had bad dreams . 7 Ever so many times in the night he had waked up , a very unusual thing for Happy Jack . 8 The fact is , he had something on his mind . 9 Yes , Sir , Happy Jack had something on his mind , and that something was Farmer Brown 's boy . 10 He often had had Farmer Brown 's boy on his mind before , but in a very different way . 11 Then it had been in the days when Farmer Brown 's boy hunted through the Green Forest and over the Green Meadows with his terrible gun . 12 Then everybody had Farmer Brown 's boy on their minds most of the time . 13 Happy Jack had hated him then , hated him because he had feared him . 14 You know fear almost always leads to hate . 15 But now it was different . 16 Farmer Brown 's boy had put away his terrible gun . 17 Happy Jack no longer feared him . 18 Love had taken the place of hate in his heart , for had not Farmer Brown 's boy saved him from Shadow the Weasel , and brought him nuts and corn when food was scarce ? 19 And now Tommy Tit had brought word that some thing was the matter with Farmer Brown 's boy . 20 It was this that was on Happy Jack 's mind and had given him such a bad night . 1 Now he really had n't thought of moving until that very minute . 2 And he did n't know why he had said it . 3 But he had said it , and because he is an obstinate little fellow he stuck to it . 4 `` When can I move in ? '' 5 asked Jimmy Skunk , his eyes twinkling . 6 `` Right away , if you want to , '' replied Johnny Chuck , and swaggered off down the Lone Little Path , leaving Jimmy Skunk to stare after him as if he thought Johnny Chuck had suddenly gone crazy , as indeed he did . 7 VI JOHNNY CHUCK TURNS TRAMP Johnny Chuck had turned tramp . 8 Yes , Sir , Johnny Chuck had turned tramp . 9 It was a funny thing to do , but he had done it . 10 He did n't know why he had done it , excepting that he had become dissatisfied and discontented and unhappy in his old home . 11 And then , almost without thinking what he was doing , he had told Jimmy Skunk that he could have the house he had worked so hard to build the summer before and of which he had been so proud . 12 Then Johnny Chuck had swaggered away down the Lone Little Path without once looking back at the home he was leaving . 13 Where was he going ? 14 Well , to tell the truth , Johnny did n't know . 15 He was going to see the world , and perhaps when he had seen the world , he would build him a new house . 16 So as long as he was in sight of Jimmy Skunk , he swaggered along quite as if he was used to traveling about , without any snug house to go to at night . 17 But right down in his heart Johnny Chuck did n't feel half so bold as he pretended . 18 You see , not since he was a little Chuck and had run away from old Mother Chuck with Peter Rabbit , had he ever been very far from his own door-step . 19 He had always been content to grow fat and roly-poly right near his own home , and listen to the tales of the great world from Jimmy Skunk and Peter Rabbit and Bobby Coon and Unc ' Billy Possum , all of whom are great travelers . 20 But now , here he was , actually setting forth , and without a home to come back to ! 1 But this morning he was thinking and thinking hard , so hard , in fact , that he almost lost his temper when Sammy Jay interrupted his thoughts with such a foolish question . 2 What was he thinking about ? 3 Can you not guess ? 4 Why , he was thinking about those big , fat hickory nuts that Striped Chipmunk had had for his Thanksgiving dinner , and how Striped Chipmunk had given him some of them to bring home . 5 He was very sure that they were the very same nuts that he had watched grow big and fat in the top of the tall hickory tree and then had knocked down while chasing his cousin , Chatterer . 6 When they had reached the ground and found the nuts gone , Happy Jack had at once suspected that Striped Chipmunk had taken them , and now he felt sure about it . 7 But all at once things looked very different to Happy Jack , and the more he thought about how he had acted , the more ashamed of himself he grew . 8 `` There certainly must have been enough of those nuts for all of us , and if I had n't been so greedy we might all have had a share . 9 As it is , I 've got only those that Striped Chipmunk gave me , and Chatterer has only those that Striped Chipmunk gave him . 10 It must be that that sharp little cousin of mine with the striped coat has got the rest , and I guess he deserves them . '' 11 Then all of a sudden Happy Jack realized how Striped Chipmunk had fooled him into thinking that the storehouse of Chatterer was his storehouse , and Happy Jack began to laugh . 12 The more he thought of it , the harder he laughed . 13 `` The joke certainly is on me ! '' 14 he exclaimed . 15 `` The joke certainly is on me , and it served me right . 16 Hereafter I 'll mind my own business . 17 If I had spent half as much time looking for hickory nuts as I did looking for Striped Chipmunk 's storehouse , I would be ready for winter now , and Chatterer could n't call me a thief . '' 18 Then he laughed again as he thought how Striped Chipmunk must have enjoyed seeing him pulled out of Chatterer 's storehouse by the tail . 19 `` What 's the joke ? '' 20 asked Bobby Coon , who happened along just then . 1 He did n't know just why , but right down deep inside he had a sudden feeling that he really did n't care a thing about that old home . 2 In fact , he felt as if he would n't care if he never had another home . 3 Yes , Sir , that is the way that Johnny Chuck felt . 4 Do you know why ? 5 Just because he had just begun to realize how big and strong he really was . 6 Now it is a splendid thing to feel big and strong and brave , a very splendid thing ! 7 But it is a bad thing to let that feeling turn to pride , foolish pride . 8 Of course old Whitetail had n't really been afraid of Johnny Chuck . 9 He had simply passed Johnny with a wink , because there was plenty to eat without the trouble of fighting , and Whitetail does n't fight just for the fun of it . 10 But foolish Johnny Chuck really thought that old Whitetail was afraid of him . 11 The more he thought about it , the more tickled he felt and the more puffed up he felt . 12 He began to talk to himself and to brag . 13 Yes , Sir , Johnny Chuck began to brag : `` I 'm not afraid of any one ; They 're all afraid of me ! 14 I only have to show my teeth To make them turn and flee ! ' 10 But this time he met with no success , for the donkey took no more notice of the magic word than he would have done if a lyre had been twanged in his ear . 11 Two , three , and four times did Antonio pronounce ` Bricklebrit , ' but all in vain , and he might as well have spoken to the wind . 12 Disgusted and furious with the poor creature , he seized a thick stick and began to beat it so hard that he nearly broke every bone in its body . 13 The miserable donkey was so distracted at such treatment that , far from pouring out precious stones , it only tore and dirtied all the fine linen . 14 When poor Masella saw her table-cloths and sheets being destroyed , and that instead of becoming rich she had only been made a fool of , she seized another stick and belaboured Antonio so unmercifully with it , that he fled before her , and never stopped till he reached the ogre 's cave . 15 When his master saw the lad returning in such a sorry plight , he understood at once what had happened to him , and making no bones about the matter , he told Antonio what a fool he had been to allow himself to be so imposed upon by the landlord , and to let a worthless animal be palmed off on him instead of his magic donkey . 16 Antonio listened humbly to the ogre 's words , and vowed solemnly that he would never act so foolishly again . 17 And so a year passed , and once more Antonio was overcome by a fit of home-sickness , and felt a great longing to see his own people again . 18 Now the ogre , although he was so hideous to look upon , had a very kind heart , and when he saw how restless and unhappy Antonio was , he at once gave him leave to go home on a visit . 19 At parting he gave him a beautiful table-cloth , and said : ` Give this to your mother ; but see that you do n't lose it as you lost the donkey , and till you are safely in your own house beware of saying `` Table-cloth , open , '' and `` Table-cloth , shut . ' 6 When they had reached the thickest part of the wood , Bobino got out of the carriage , and having said good-bye to the servants set out on his wanderings . 7 On and on he walked , till at last , late in the evening , he came to a house where some herdsmen lived . 8 He knocked at the door and begged for shelter for the night . 9 The herdsmen , seeing how gentle a youth he seemed , made him welcome , and bade him sit down and share their supper . 10 While they were eating it , the dog in the courtyard began to bark . 11 Bobino walked to the window , listened attentively for a minute , and then turning to the herdsmen said : ` Send your wives and daughters at once to bed , and arm yourselves as best you can , because at midnight a band of robbers will attack this house . ' 4 Very soon -- sooner than he expected -- a chance came , and Fortunatus , like a wise boy , seized on it at once . 5 The post offered him was that of page to the Earl of Flanders , and as the Earl whole days , with nothing to eat and very little water to drink , going first in one direction and then in another , but never being able to find his way out . 13 During the first night he slept soundly , and was too tired to fear either man or beast , but when darkness came on for the second time , and growls were heard in the distance , he grew frightened and looked about for a high tree out of reach of his enemies . 14 Hardly had he settled himself comfortably in one of the forked branches , when a lion walked up to a spring that burst from a rock close to the tree , and crouching , and I soon found myself in a far distant region transformed into a little dog , under which shape I had the honour to meet your Majesty . 18 After six months , the queen 's vengeance not being yet satisfied , she further changed me into a hideous old man , and in this form I was so afraid of being unpleasant in your eyes , Madam , that I hid myself in the depths of the woods , where I spent three months more . 19 At the end of that time I was so fortunate as to meet a benevolent fairy who delivered me from the proud queen 's power , and told me all your adventures and where to find you . 20 I now come to offer you a heart which has been entirely yours , Madam , since first we met in the desert . '' 19 CHAPTER XII . 20 FLOWERS O ' MAY Accordingly we went a-maying , following the lure of dancing winds to a certain westward sloping hill lying under the spirit-like blue of spring skies , feathered over with lisping young pines and firs , which cupped little hollows and corners where the sunshine got in and never got out again , but stayed there and grew mellow , coaxing dear things to bloom long before they would dream of waking up elsewhere . 1 Quickeye ! 2 Do you know what has become of the princess ? ' 3 Quickeye rubbed his eyes and answered : ` Yes , I see her . 4 Two hundred miles from here there is a mountain . 5 In this mountain is a rock . 6 In the rock , a precious stone . 7 This stone is the princess . 8 Long shall take me there , and we will be back before you can turn round . ' 9 So Long took him on his shoulders and they set out . 10 At every stride they covered twenty miles , and as they drew near Quickeye fixed his burning eyes on the mountain ; in an instant it split into a thousand pieces , and in one of these sparkled the precious stone . 11 They picked it up and brought it to the prince , who flung it hastily down , and as the stone touched the floor the princess stood before him . 12 When the wizard came , his eyes shot forth flames of fury . 13 Cric-crac was heard , and another of his iron bands broke and fell . 14 He seized the princess by the hand and led her off , growling louder than ever . 15 All that day things went on exactly as they had done the day before . 16 After supper the wizard brought back the princess , and looking him straight in the eyes he said , ` We shall see which of us two will gain the prize after all ! '' 13 CHAPTER XXIII . 14 A MISSIONARY HEROINE Accordingly , that afternoon we bearded the lion in his den . 15 The road we took was a beautiful one , for we went `` cross lots , '' and we enjoyed it , in spite of the fact that we did not expect the interview with Mr. Campbell to be a very pleasant one . 16 To be sure , he had been quite civil on the occasion of our last call upon him , but the Story Girl had been with us then and had beguiled him into good-humour and generosity by the magic of her voice and personality . 17 We had no such ally now , and Mr. Campbell was known to be virulently opposed to missions in any shape or form . 18 `` I do n't know whether it would have been any better if I could have put on my good clothes , '' said Cecily , with a rueful glance at her print dress , which , though neat and clean , was undeniably faded and RATHER short and tight . 19 `` The Story Girl said it would , and I wanted to , but mother would n't let me . 20 She said it was all nonsense , and Mr. Campbell would never notice what I had on . '' 3 `` I never heard such nonsense , '' declared Felicity . 4 The rest of us were rather inclined to agree with her for once . 5 We thought the Story Girl was making fun of us . 6 But I believe she really had a strange gift of thinking in colours . 7 In later years , when we were grown up , she told me of it again . 8 She said that everything had colour in her thought ; the months of the year ran through all the tints of the spectrum , the days of the week were arrayed as Solomon in his glory , morning was golden , noon orange , evening crystal blue , and night violet . 9 Every idea came to her mind robed in its own especial hue . 10 Perhaps that was why her voice and words had such a charm , conveying to the listeners ' perception such fine shadings of meaning and tint and music . 11 `` Well , let 's go and have something to eat , '' suggested Dan . 12 `` What colour is eating , Sara ? '' 9 If you do , the misfortune be on your own head , for I have given you fair warning . ' 10 Antonio set out on his journey , but hardly had he got out of sight of the cave than he laid the table-cloth on the ground and said , ` Table-cloth , open . ' 1 Perhaps those singers were not birds at all ! 2 Why had n't he thought of that before ? 3 Perhaps it was because he was looking so hard for birds that he had n't seen anything else . 4 Johnny began to look , not for anything in particular , but to see everything that he could . 5 Almost right away he saw some tiny little dark spots on the water . 6 They did n't look like much of anything . 7 They were so small that he had n't noticed them before . 8 One of them was quite close to him , and as Johnny Chuck looked at it , it began to look like a tiny nose , and then -- why , just then , Johnny was very sure that one of those singing voices came right from that very spot ! 9 He was so surprised that he hopped to his feet and excitedly beckoned to Jerry Muskrat . 10 The instant he did that , the voices near him stopped singing , and the little spots on the water disappeared , leaving just the tiniest of little rings , just such tiny little rings as drops of rain falling on the Smiling Pool would make . 11 And when that tiny spot nearest to him that looked like a tiny nose disappeared , Johnny Chuck caught just a glimpse of a little form under the water . 12 `` Why -- why-e-e ! 13 The singers are Grandfather Frog 's children ! '' 5 So saying , our father fell back on his cushions and died , leaving us burning with desire for the three rings of the daughters of Siroco . 6 ` No sooner were our sad duties finished than we began to make inquiries where these young ladies were to be found , and we learned after much trouble that Siroco , their father , had fought in many wars , and that his daughters , whose beauty was famous throughout all the land , were named Aurora , Argentine , and Zelida . ' 7 At the second of these names , both the Bassa and his son gave a start of surprise , but they said nothing , and Izaf went on with his story . 8 ` The first thing to be done was to put on a disguise , and it was in the dress of foreign merchants that we at length approached the young ladies , taking care to carry with us a collection of fine stones which we had hired for the occasion . 9 But alas ! 10 it was to no purpose that Nathan Ben-Sadi had warned us to close our hearts against their charms ! 11 The peerless Aurora was clothed in a garment of golden hue , studded all over with flashing jewels ; the fair-haired Argentine wore a dress of silver , and the young Zelida , loveliest of them all , the costume of a Persian lady . 12 ` Among other curiosities that we had brought with us , was a flask containing an elixir which had the quality of exciting love in the breasts of any man or woman who drank of it . 13 This had been given me by the fair Sumi , who had used it herself and was full of wrath because I refused to drink it likewise , and so return her passion . 14 I showed this liquid to the three maidens who were engaged in examining the precious stones , and choosing those that pleased them best ; and I was in the act of pouring some in a crystal cup , when Zelida 's eyes fell on a paper wrapped round the flask containing these words : `` Beware lest you drink this water with any other man than him who will one day be your husband . '' 11 CHAPTER XII . 12 FLOWERS O ' MAY Accordingly we went a-maying , following the lure of dancing winds to a certain westward sloping hill lying under the spirit-like blue of spring skies , feathered over with lisping young pines and firs , which cupped little hollows and corners where the sunshine got in and never got out again , but stayed there and grew mellow , coaxing dear things to bloom long before they would dream of waking up elsewhere . 13 'T was there we found our mayflowers , after faithful seeking . 14 Mayflowers , you must know , never flaunt themselves ; they must be sought as becomes them , and then they will yield up their treasures to the seeker -- clusters of star-white and dawn-pink that have in them the very soul of all the springs that ever were , re-incarnated in something it seems gross to call perfume , so exquisite and spiritual is it . 15 We wandered gaily over the hill , calling to each other with laughter and jest , getting parted and delightfully lost in that little pathless wilderness , and finding each other unexpectedly in nooks and dips and sunny silences , where the wind purred and gentled and went softly . 16 When the sun began to hang low , sending great fan-like streamers of radiance up to the zenith , we foregathered in a tiny , sequestered valley , full of young green fern , lying in the shadow of a wooded hill . 17 In it was a shallow pool -- a glimmering green sheet of water on whose banks nymphs might dance as blithely as ever they did on Argive hill or in Cretan dale . 18 There we sat and stripped the faded leaves and stems from our spoil , making up the blossoms into bouquets to fill our baskets with sweetness . 19 The Story Girl twisted a spray of divinest pink in her brown curls , and told us an old legend of a beautiful Indian maiden who died of a broken heart when the first snows of winter were falling , because she believed her long-absent lover was false . 20 But he came back in the spring time from his long captivity ; ' 13 ` Ah , my son , I have reason enough to be sad ; but for me you would now have been enjoying every kind of pleasure , instead of being buried in this tiny house . ' 16 A few moments later our parents came to tell us that the escort had arrived , and having taken farewell of them we mounted the camels , and took our seats in a kind of box that was fixed to the side of the animal . 17 These boxes were large enough for us to sleep in comfortably , and as there was a window in the upper part , we were able to see the country through which we passed . 18 ` For several days we journeyed on , feeling sad and anxious as to what might become of us , when one day as I was looking out of the window of our room , I heard my name called , and beheld a beautifully dressed girl jumping out of the box on the other side of our camel . 19 One glance told me that it was the prince , and my heart bounded with joy . 20 It was , he said , Thelamis 's idea to disguise him like this , and that he himself had assumed the character of a slave-dealer who was taking this peerless maiden as a present to the Sultan . 1 The poor girls were not so fortunate . 2 They always averred they never closed an eye . 3 Four things prevented them from sleeping . 4 In the first place Peg snored loudly ; ' 1 After a night passed in a soft bed , Fortunatus felt so much better that he asked the landlord if he could find him some men-servants , and tell him where any good horses were to be got . 2 The next thing was to provide himself with smart clothes , and then to take a big house where he could give great feasts to the nobles and beautiful ladies who lived in palaces round about . 3 In this manner a whole year soon slipped away , and Fortunatus was so busy amusing himself that he never once remembered his parents whom he had left behind in Cyprus . 4 But though he was thoughtless , he was not bad-hearted . 5 As soon as their existence crossed his mind , he set about making preparations to visit them , and as he was not fond of being alone he looked round for some one older and wiser than himself to travel with him . 6 It was not long before he had the good luck to come across an old man who had left his wife and children in a far country many years before , when he went out into the world to seek the fortune which he never found . 7 He agreed to accompany Fortunatus back to Cyprus , but only on condition he should first be allowed to return for a few weeks to his own home before venturing to set sail for an island so strange and distant . 8 Fortunatus agreed to his proposal , and as he was always fond of anything new , said that he would go with him . 9 The journey was long , and they had to cross many large rivers , and climb over high mountains , and find their way through thick woods , before they reached at length the old man 's castle . 10 His wife and children had almost given up hopes of seeing him again , and crowded eagerly round him . 11 Indeed , it did not take Fortunatus five minutes to fall in love with the youngest daughter , the most beautiful creature in the whole world , whose name was Cassandra . 12 ` Give her to me for my wife , ' he said to the old man , ` and let us all go together to Famagosta . '' 1 Rollicking robins were whistling joyously in the pines . 2 Jasper Dale 's heart was filled to over-flowing with a realization of all the virgin loveliness around him ; the feeling in his soul had the sacredness of a prayer . 3 At this moment he looked up and saw Alice Reade . 4 She was standing outside the garden fence , in the shadow of a great pine tree , looking not at him , for she was unaware of his presence , but at the virginal bloom of the plum trees in a far corner , with all her delight in it outblossoming freely in her face . 5 For a moment Jasper Dale believed that his dream love had taken visible form before him . 6 She was like -- so like ; him as sweet Cecily could be to anyone , but the gallant Cyrus was nothing daunted . 14 He laid determined siege to Cecily 's young heart by all the methods known to love-lorn swains . 15 He placed entreated to be allowed to carry her basket from school ; he offered to work her sums for her ; and rumour had it that he had made a wild statement to the effect that he meant to ask if he might see her home some night from prayer meeting . 16 Cecily was quite frightened that he would ; she confided to me that she would rather die than walk home with him , but that if he asked her she would be too bashful to say no . 17 So far , however , Cyrus had not molested her out of school , nor had he as yet thumped Willy Fraser -- who was reported to be very low in his spirits over the whole affair . 18 And now Cyrus had written Cecily a letter -- a love letter , mark you . 19 Moreover , he had sent it through the post-office , with a real stamp on it . 20 Its arrival made a sensation among us . '' 7 Then each little Chuck would sit up very straight and not move the teeniest , weeniest bit , so that from a little distance they looked for all the world like tiny stumps . 8 But all the time their sharp little eyes would be looking this way and that way , to see what the danger might be . 9 After a while Johnny would give another little whistle , which meant `` Danger past . '' 10 Then they would once more begin to fill their little stomachs with sweet , tender , young clover . 11 Sometimes , however , Johnny would whistle sharply . 12 That meant `` Run ! '' 13 Then they would scamper as fast as they could along the nearest little path to the house under the old apple-tree in the far corner , and never once look around . 14 They would dive head first , one after the other , in at the doorway , and not show their noses outside again until Johnny or Polly Chuck told them they could . 15 Then there was a still different whistle . 16 It meant `` Danger very near ; lie low ! '' 17 When they heard that , they flattened themselves right down in the grass just wherever they happened to be , and held their breath and did n't move until Johnny signaled that they might . 18 Of course , there never was any real danger . 19 Johnny was just teaching them , so that when danger did come , as it surely would , sooner or later , they would know just what to do . 20 It surely was a funny little school , and sometimes Sammy Jay had hard work to keep from laughing right out . 1 When he had been three more years in the ogre 's service he had another bad fit of home-sickness , and longed very much to see his mother and sisters again . 2 So he asked for permission to go home on a visit , and it was at once granted to him . 3 Before he set out on his journey the ogre presented him with a beautifully carved stick and said , ` Take this stick as a remembrance of me ; but beware of saying , `` Rise up , Stick , '' and `` Lie down , Stick , '' for if you do , I can only say I would n't be in your shoes for something . ' 1 He told them that he was a king 's son , who had been banished to this castle by a wicked magician , and that he had been changed into the three-headed dwarf . 2 When he had lost two of his heads the magic power over the two princesses had been removed , and when the blacksmith had killed the horrible dog , then he too had been set free . 3 To show his gratitude he begged the three companions to divide the treasure between them , which they did ; but there was so much of it that it took a very long time . 4 The princesses , too , were so grateful to their rescuers , that one married the blacksmith , and the other the countryman . 5 Then the prince claimed the nun as his bride , and they all lived happily together till they died . 6 -LSB- From the German , Kletke . -RSB- 7 HERR LAZARUS AND THE DRAKEN Once upon a time there was a cobbler called Lazarus , who was very fond of honey . 8 One day , as he ate some while he sat at work , the flies collected in such numbers that with one blow he killed forty . 9 Then he went and ordered a sword to be made for him , on which he had written these words : ` With one blow I have slain forty . ' 10 When the sword was ready he took it and went out into the world , and when he was two days ' journey from home he came to a spring , by which he laid himself down and slept . 11 Now in that country there dwelt Draken , one of whom came to the spring to draw water ; there he found Lazarus sleeping , and read what was written on his sword . 12 Then he went back to his people and told them what he had seen , and they all advised him to make fellowship with this powerful stranger . 13 So the Draken returned to the spring , awoke Lazarus , and said that if it was agreeable to him they should make fellowship together . 14 -LSB- Illustration : How THE DRAKEN FOUND HERR LAZARUS ASLEEP by the SPRING -RSB- Lazarus answered that he was willing , and after a priest had blessed the fellowship , they returned together to the other Draken , and Lazarus dwelt among them . 15 After some days they told him that it was their custom to take it in turns to bring wood and water , and as he was now of their company , he must take his turn . 16 They went first for water and wood , but at last it came to be Lazarus 's turn to go for water . 17 The Draken had a great leathern bag , holding two hundred measures of water . 18 This Lazarus could only , with great difficulty , drag empty to the spring , and because he could not carry it back full , he did not fill it at all , but , instead , he dug up the ground all round the spring . 19 As Lazarus remained so long away , the Draken sent one of their number to see what had become of him , and when this one came to the spring , Lazarus said to him : ` We will no more plague ourselves by carrying water every day . 20 I will bring the entire spring home at once , and so we shall be freed from this burden . '' 4 CHAPTER XVIII HAPPY JACK DECIDES TO MAKE A CALL You 'll find when all is said and done Two heads are better far than one . 5 Happy Jack . 6 Happy Jack Squirrel had n't slept very well . 7 He had had bad dreams . 8 Ever so many times in the night he had waked up , a very unusual thing for Happy Jack . 9 The fact is , he had something on his mind . 10 Yes , Sir , Happy Jack had something on his mind , and that something was Farmer Brown 's boy . 11 He often had had Farmer Brown 's boy on his mind before , but in a very different way . 12 Then it had been in the days when Farmer Brown 's boy hunted through the Green Forest and over the Green Meadows with his terrible gun . 13 Then everybody had Farmer Brown 's boy on their minds most of the time . 14 Happy Jack had hated him then , hated him because he had feared him . 15 You know fear almost always leads to hate . 16 But now it was different . 17 Farmer Brown 's boy had put away his terrible gun . 18 Happy Jack no longer feared him . 19 Love had taken the place of hate in his heart , for had not Farmer Brown 's boy saved him from Shadow the Weasel , and brought him nuts and corn when food was scarce ? 20 And now Tommy Tit had brought word that some thing was the matter with Farmer Brown 's boy . 1 `` If her hair was n't so white she would n't look much older than your mother . ' 1 Can you think of anything more dreadful than to be afraid to go to your own home ? 2 Why , home is the dearest place in the world , and it should be the safest . 3 Just think how you would feel if you should be away from home , and then you should learn that it would n't be safe for you to go back there again , and you had no other place to go . 4 It often happens that way with the little people of the Green Meadows and the Green Forest . 5 It was that way with Happy Jack Squirrel now . 6 You see , Happy Jack knew that Shadow the Weasel is not one to give up easily . 7 Shadow has one very good trait , and that is persistence . 8 He is not easily discouraged . 9 When he sets out to do a thing , usually he does it . 10 If he starts to get a thing , usually he gets it . 11 No , he is n't easily discouraged . 12 Happy Jack knows this . 13 No one knows it better . 14 So Happy Jack did n't dare to go home . 15 He knew that any minute of night or day Shadow might surprise him there , and that would be the end of him . 16 He more than half suspected that Shadow was at that very time hiding somewhere along the way ready to spring out on him if he should try to go back home . 17 He had stayed in the room of Farmer Brown 's boy until Mrs. Brown had come to make the bed . 18 Then he had jumped out the window into the big maple tree . 19 He was n't quite sure of Mrs. Brown yet . 20 She had kindly eyes . 1 `` Is n't he a member of the church ? ' 7 When a year had gone by , it chanced , one day , that the king 's cooper passed the stables where Cannetella was kept prisoner . 8 She recognised the man , and called him to come in . 9 At first he did not know the poor princess , and could not make out who it was that called him by name . 10 But when he heard Cannetella 's tale of woe , he hid her in a big empty barrel he had with him , partly because he was sorry for the poor girl , and , even more , because he wished to gain the king 's favour . 11 Then he slung the barrel on the mule 's back , and in this way the princess was carried to her own home . 12 They arrived at the palace about four o'clock in the morning , and the cooper knocked loudly at the door . 13 When the servants came in haste and saw only the cooper standing at the gate , they were very indignant , and scolded him soundly for coming at such an hour and waking them all out of their sleep . 14 The king hearing the noise and the cause of it , sent for the cooper , for he felt certain the man must have some important business , to have come and disturbed the whole palace at such an early hour . 15 The cooper asked permission to unload his mule , and Cannetella crept out of the barrel . 16 At first the king refused to believe that it was really his daughter , for she had changed so terribly in a few years , and had grown so thin and pale , that it was pitiful to see her . 17 At last the princess showed her father a mole she had on her right arm , and then he saw that the poor girl was indeed his long-lost Cannetella . 18 He kissed her a thousand times , and instantly had the choicest food and drink set before her . 19 -LSB- Illustration : CANNETELLA COMES OUT OF THE CASK -RSB- After she had satisfied her hunger , the king said to her : ` Who would have thought , my dear daughter , to have found you in such a state ? 20 What , may I ask , has brought you to this pass ? 15 Grandfather King was so amazed he could n't laugh , but almost everyone else in the church was laughing , and grandfather said he never blamed them , for no funnier sight was ever seen . 16 Young Isaac turned into grandfather 's pew and thumped the bag of oatmeal down on the seat with a thud that cracked it . 17 Then he plumped down beside it , took off his hat , wiped his face , and settled back to listen to the sermon , just as if it was all a matter of course . 18 When the service was over he hoisted his bag up again , marched out of church , and drove home . 19 He could never understand why it made so much talk ; but he was known by the name of Oatmeal Frewen for years . '' 20 Our laughter , as we separated , rang sweetly through the old orchard and across the far , dim meadows . 1 Happy Jack . 2 Happy Jack did n't dare go home . 3 Can you think of anything more dreadful than to be afraid to go to your own home ? 4 Why , home is the dearest place in the world , and it should be the safest . 5 Just think how you would feel if you should be away from home , and then you should learn that it would n't be safe for you to go back there again , and you had no other place to go . 6 It often happens that way with the little people of the Green Meadows and the Green Forest . 7 It was that way with Happy Jack Squirrel now . 8 You see , Happy Jack knew that Shadow the Weasel is not one to give up easily . 9 Shadow has one very good trait , and that is persistence . 10 He is not easily discouraged . 11 When he sets out to do a thing , usually he does it . 12 If he starts to get a thing , usually he gets it . 13 No , he is n't easily discouraged . 14 Happy Jack knows this . 15 No one knows it better . 16 So Happy Jack did n't dare to go home . 17 He knew that any minute of night or day Shadow might surprise him there , and that would be the end of him . 18 He more than half suspected that Shadow was at that very time hiding somewhere along the way ready to spring out on him if he should try to go back home . 19 He had stayed in the room of Farmer Brown 's boy until Mrs. Brown had come to make the bed . 20 Then he had jumped out the window into the big maple tree . 1 He remembered Happy Jack 's fright that morning . 2 `` I know what 's the matter ! '' 3 he said to her and me , one idle afternoon of opal skies , pied meadows and misty hills . 4 It was Saturday and Peter had gone home ; Felix and Dan were helping Uncle Alec top turnips ; Cecily and Felicity were making cookies for Sunday , so the Story Girl and I were alone in Uncle Stephen 's Walk . 5 We liked to be alone together that last month , to think the long , long thoughts of youth and talk about our futures . 6 There had grown up between us that summer a bond of sympathy that did not exist between us and the others . 7 We were older than they -- the Story Girl was fifteen and I was nearly that ; and all at once it seemed as if we were immeasurably older than the rest , and possessed of dreams and visions and forward-reaching hopes which they could not possibly share or understand . 8 At times we were still children , still interested in childish things . 9 But there came hours when we seemed to our two selves very grown up and old , and in those hours we talked our dreams and visions and hopes , vague and splendid , as all such are , over together , and so began to build up , out of the rainbow fragments of our childhood 's companionship , that rare and beautiful friendship which was to last all our lives , enriching and enstarring them . 10 For there is no bond more lasting than that formed by the mutual confidences of that magic time when youth is slipping from the sheath of childhood and beginning to wonder what lies for it beyond those misty hills that bound the golden road . 11 `` Where are you going ? '' 1 Never was anything so gorgeous as the maple trees that year . 2 Maples are trees that have primeval fire in their souls . 3 It glows out a little in their early youth , before the leaves open , in the redness and rosy-yellowness of their blossoms , but in summer it is carefully hidden under a demure , silver-lined greenness . 4 Then when autumn comes , the maples give up trying to be sober and flame out in all the barbaric splendour and gorgeousness of their real nature , making of the hills things out of an Arabian Nights dream in the golden prime of good Haroun Alraschid . 5 You may never know what scarlet and crimson really are until you see them in their perfection on an October hillside , under the unfathomable blue of an autumn sky . 6 All the glow and radiance and joy at earth 's heart seem to have broken loose in a splendid determination to express itself for once before the frost of winter chills her beating pulses . 7 It is the year 's carnival ere the dull Lenten days of leafless valleys and penitential mists come . 8 The time of apple-picking had come around once more and we worked joyously . 9 Uncle Blair picked apples with us , and between him and the Story Girl it was an October never to be forgotten . 10 `` Will you go far afield for a walk with me to-day ? '' 11 he said to her and me , one idle afternoon of opal skies , pied meadows and misty hills . 12 It was Saturday and Peter had gone home ; Felix and Dan were helping Uncle Alec top turnips ; Cecily and Felicity were making cookies for Sunday , so the Story Girl and I were alone in Uncle Stephen 's Walk . 13 We liked to be alone together that last month , to think the long , long thoughts of youth and talk about our futures . 14 There had grown up between us that summer a bond of sympathy that did not exist between us and the others . 15 We were older than they -- the Story Girl was fifteen and I was nearly that ; and all at once it seemed as if we were immeasurably older than the rest , and possessed of dreams and visions and forward-reaching hopes which they could not possibly share or understand . 16 At times we were still children , still interested in childish things . 17 But there came hours when we seemed to our two selves very grown up and old , and in those hours we talked our dreams and visions and hopes , vague and splendid , as all such are , over together , and so began to build up , out of the rainbow fragments of our childhood 's companionship , that rare and beautiful friendship which was to last all our lives , enriching and enstarring them . 18 For there is no bond more lasting than that formed by the mutual confidences of that magic time when youth is slipping from the sheath of childhood and beginning to wonder what lies for it beyond those misty hills that bound the golden road . 19 `` Where are you going ? ' 1 Sometimes he would find her shyly peeping at him from behind a clump of grass . 2 Then Johnny Chuck would try to make himself look very important , and would strut about as if he really did own the Green Meadows . 3 Sometimes she would hide from him , and when he found her she would run away . 4 Other times she would be just as nice to him as she could be , and they would have a jolly time hunting for sweet clover and other nice things to eat . 5 Then Johnny Chuck 's heart would swell until it seemed to him that it would fairly burst with happiness . 6 Instead of wanting to drive Polly Chuck away from the Green Meadows , as he had the old gray Chuck , Johnny began to worry for fear that Polly Chuck might not stay on the Green Meadows . 7 Whenever he thought of that , his heart would sink way , way down , and he would hurry to look for her and make sure that she was still there . 8 When he was beside her , he felt very big and strong and brave and longed for a chance to show her how brave he was . 9 She was such a timid little thing herself that the least little thing frightened her , and Johnny Chuck was glad that this was so , for it gave him a chance to protect her . 10 When he was n't with her , he spent his time looking for new patches of sweet clover to take her to . 11 At first she would n't go without a great deal of coaxing , but after a while he did n't have to coax at all . 12 She seemed to delight to be with him as much as he did to be with her . 13 So Johnny Chuck grew happier and happier . 14 He was happier than he had ever been in all his life before . 15 You see Johnny Chuck had found the greatest thing in the world . 16 Do you know what it is ? 17 It is called love . 18 XII JOHNNY CHUCK PROVES HIS LOVE These spring days were beautiful days on the Green Meadows . 19 It seemed to Johnny Chuck that the Green Meadows never had been so lovely or the songs of the birds so sweet . 20 He had forgotten all about his old friends , Jimmy Skunk and Peter Rabbit and the other little meadow people . 1 In the last one stood a dish , covered with food , which reminded him that he was hungry , and he sat down and ate and drank . 2 Months passed away , when , one morning , as he was walking through the halls , he noticed a purse hanging on the wall , which had never been there before . 3 He took it down to examine it , and nearly let it fall with surprise when a voice came from the purse saying : ` What commands have you ? ' 4 ` Oh , take me out of this horrible place , and up into the world again ; ' and in a moment he was , standing by the river bank , with the purse tightly grasped in his hand . 5 ` Now let me have the most beautiful ship that ever was built , all manned and ready for sea . ' 6 And there was the ship , with a flag floating from its mast on which were the words , ` King with the three crowns . ' 7 Then Bensurdatu climbed on board , and sailed away to the city where the three princesses dwelt ; and when he reached the harbour he blew trumpets and beat drums , so that every one ran to the doors and windows . 8 And the king heard too , and saw the beautiful vessel , and said to himself : ` That must indeed be a mighty monarch , for he has three crowns while I have only one . ' 9 So he hastened to greet the stranger , and invited him to his castle , for , thought he , ` this will be a fine husband for my youngest daughter . ' 10 Now , the youngest princess had never married , and had turned a deaf ear to all her wooers . 11 Such a long time had passed since Bensurdatu had left the palace , that the king never guessed for a moment that the splendidly clad stranger before him was the man whom he had so deeply mourned as dead . 12 ` Noble lord , ' said he , ` let us feast and make merry together , and then , if it seem good to you , do me the honour to take my youngest daughter to wife . ' 13 And Bensurdatu was glad , and they all sat down to a great feast , and there were great rejoicings . 14 But only the youngest daughter was sad , for her thoughts were with Bensurdatu . 15 After they arose from the table the king said to her , ` Dear child , this mighty lord does you the honour to ask your hand in marriage . ' 16 ` Oh , father , ' answered she , ` spare me , I pray you , for I desire to remain single . ' 17 Then Bensurdatu turned to her , and said : ` And if I were Bensurdatu , would you give the same answer to me ? ' 18 And as she stood silently gazing at him , he added : ` Yes , I am Bensurdatu ; and this is my story . ' 19 The king and queen had their hearts stirred within them at the tale of his adventures , and when he had ended the king stretched out his hand , and said : ` Dear Bensurdatu , my youngest daughter shall indeed be your wife ; and when I die my crown shall be yours . 20 As for the men who have betrayed you , they shall leave the country and you shall see them no more . he had a harp and he often tried to play on it ; but his clumsy fingers only made such discord that his companions laughed at him and mocked him , and called him a madman because he would not give it up , but would rather sit apart by himself , with his arms about his harp , looking up into the sky , while they gathered around their fire and told tales to wile away their long night vigils as they watched their sheep on the hills . 15 But to him the thoughts that came out of the great silence were far sweeter than their mirth ; and he never gave up the hope , which sometimes left his lips as a prayer , that some day he might be able to express those thoughts in music to the tired , weary , forgetful world . 16 On the first Christmas night he was out with his fellow shepherds on the hills . 17 It was chill and dark , and all , except him , were glad to gather around the fire . 18 He sat , as usual , by himself , with his harp on his knee and a great longing in his heart . 19 And there came a marvellous light in the sky and over the hills , as if the darkness of the night had suddenly blossomed into a wonderful meadow of flowery flame ; and all the shepherds saw the angels and heard them sing . 20 And as they sang , the harp that the young shepherd held began to play softly by itself , and as he listened to it he realized that it was playing the same music that the angels sang and that all his secret longings and aspirations and strivings were expressed in it . 1 When they got close to the house they found that it was an old deserted castle , fast falling into ruins , but with some of the rooms in it still habitable . 2 As they were homeless they determined to take up their abode in the castle , and they arranged that one of them should always stay at home and keep house , while the other two went out into the world to seek their fortunes . 3 The lot of remaining at home fell first to the nun , and when the countryman and the blacksmith had gone out into the wood , she set to work , tidied up the house , and prepared all the food for the day . 4 As her companions did not come home for their mid-day meal , she ate up her own portion and put the rest in the oven to keep warm . 5 Just as she was sitting down to sew , the door opened and a little gray man came in , and , standing before her , said : ` Oh ! 6 how cold I am ! ' 15 The landlord , thinking he was coming in for a third piece of good fortune , gave Antonio an excellent supper ; and after he had seen him comfortably to bed , he ran to the stick , and calling to his wife to come and see the fun , he lost no time in pronouncing the words ` Rise up , Stick . ' 16 The moment he spoke the stick jumped up and beat the landlord so unmercifully that he and his wife ran screaming to Antonio , and , waking him up , pleaded for mercy . 17 When Antonio saw how successful his trick had been he said : ' I refuse to help you , unless you give me all that you have stolen from me , otherwise you will be beaten to death . ' 18 The landlord , who felt himself at death 's door already , cried out : ` Take back your property , only release me from this terrible stick ; ' and with these words he ordered the donkey , the table-cloth , and other treasures to be restored to their rightful owner . 19 As soon as Antonio had recovered his belongings he said ` Stick , lie down , ' and it stopped beating the landlord at once . 20 Then he took his donkey and table-cloth and arrived safely at his home with them . 1 In a little time they came to the conclusion that the ships must come from a friendly nation , as every vessel was decked with gay flags , streamers , and pennons , and the way was led by a small ship flying a great white flag of peace . 2 The queen sent a special messenger to the harbour , and was soon informed that the fleet belonged to the Prince of the Emerald Isles , who begged leave to land in her kingdom , and to present his humble respects to her . 3 The queen at once sent some of the court dignitaries to receive the prince and bid him welcome . 4 She awaited him seated on her throne , but rose on his appearance , and went a few steps to meet him ; then begged him to be seated , and for about an hour kept him in close conversation . 5 The prince was then conducted to a splendid suite of apartments , and the next day he asked for a private audience . 6 He was admitted to the queen 's own sitting-room , where she was sitting alone with her sister . 7 After the first greetings the prince informed the queen that he had some very strange things to tell her , which she only would know to be true . 8 ` Madam , ' said he , ' I am a neighbour of the Queen of all the Isles ; and a small isthmus connects part of my states with hers . 9 One day , when hunting a stag , I had the misfortune to meet her , and not recognising her , I did not stop to salute her with all proper ceremony . 10 You , Madam , know better than anyone how revengeful she is , and that she is also a mistress of magic . 11 I learnt both facts to my cost . 12 The ground opened under my feet , and I soon found myself in a far distant region transformed into a little dog , under which shape I had the honour to meet your Majesty . 13 After six months , the queen 's vengeance not being yet satisfied , she further changed me into a hideous old man , and in this form I was so afraid of being unpleasant in your eyes , Madam , that I hid myself in the depths of the woods , where I spent three months more . 14 At the end of that time I was so fortunate as to meet a benevolent fairy who delivered me from the proud queen 's power , and told me all your adventures and where to find you . 15 I now come to offer you a heart which has been entirely yours , Madam , since first we met in the desert . ' 16 A few days later a herald was sent through the kingdom to proclaim the joyful news of the marriage of the Queen of the Flowery Isles with the young prince . 17 They lived happily for many years , and ruled their people well . 18 As for the bad queen , whose vanity and jealousy had caused so much mischief , the Fairies took all her power away for a punishment . 19 -LSB- ` Cabinet des Fées . '' 9 ` Not knowing what else to do , we all three returned to Constantinople to ask the advice of Sumi , and found that she was already aware of our misfortunes , having read about them in the book of Moïzes . 10 The kind-hearted creature wept bitterly at our story , but , being poor herself , could give us little help . 11 At last I proposed that every morning we should sell the silver watch into which Argentine was changed , as it would return to Sumi every evening unless it was wound up with the silver key -- which was not at all likely . 12 Sumi consented , but only on the condition that we would never sell the watch without ascertaining the house where it was to be found , so that she might also take Aurora thither , and thus Argentine would not be alone if by any chance she was wound up at the mystic hour . 13 For some weeks now we have lived by this means , and the two daughters of Siroco have never failed to return to Sumi each night . 14 Yesterday Izouf sold the silver watch to this young man , and in the evening placed the gold watch on the steps by order of Sumi , just before his customer entered the house ; from which both watches came back early this morning . '' 20 CHAPTER XXIII SAMMY JAY IS QUITE UPSET I know of nothing sweeter than Success to Squirrel or to man . 1 With flashing eyes she tore open the letter , snatched up the chalk , and dashed at the blackboard . 2 In a few minutes the contents of that letter graced the expanse usually sacred to more prosaic compositions . 3 I can not reproduce it verbatim , for I had no after opportunity of refreshing my memory . 4 But I remember that it was exceedingly sentimental and exceedingly ill-spelled -- for Cecily mercilessly copied down poor Cyrus ' mistakes . 5 He wrote her that he wore her hare over his hart -- `` and he stole it , '' Cecily threw passionately over her shoulder at Mr. Perkins -- that her eyes were so sweet and lovely that he could n't find words nice enuf to describ them , that he could never forget how butiful she had looked in prar meeting the evening before , and that some meels he could n't eat for thinking of her , with more to the same effect and he signed it `` yours till deth us do part , Cyrus Brisk . ' 11 Then Letiko went straight home , and said to her mother : ` While I was gathering herbs a fine tall gentleman came to me and charged me to tell you that you should remember what you promised him . '' 3 When they heard that , they flattened themselves right down in the grass just wherever they happened to be , and held their breath and did n't move until Johnny signaled that they might . 4 Of course , there never was any real danger . 5 Johnny was just teaching them , so that when danger did come , as it surely would , sooner or later , they would know just what to do . 6 It surely was a funny little school , and sometimes Sammy Jay had hard work to keep from laughing right out . 7 XXIV SAMMY JAY PROVES THAT HE IS NOT ALL BAD Sammy Jay had n't had so much fun for a long time as he found in watching the funny little school in Farmer Brown 's old orchard , where Johnny Chuck was teaching his three baby Chucks the things that every little Chuck must learn , if he would grow up into a big Chuck . 8 When they had learned to mind without waiting to ask why , and had learned the signals which told them just what to do when danger was near , Johnny began to lead them farther and farther away from home . 9 He took them up along the old stone wall and showed them how to find safe hiding-places among the stones . 10 Then he took them off a little way and suddenly gave the danger signal . 11 It was funny , very funny indeed to see the three little Chucks scamper for the old stone wall and crawl out of sight . 12 The first time , two of them tried to squeeze into the same hole together , and each was in such a hurry that he would n't let the other go first . 13 Then both lost their tempers and they began to fight about it , quite forgetting that if there was really any danger near , they surely would come to harm . 14 Such a scolding as Johnny Chuck did give those two little Chucks ! 15 Then he made them try it all over again . 16 Once he found a foot print which Reddy Fox had made in some soft earth during the night , and made each little Chuck smell of it , while he told them all about Reddy and old Granny Fox and how smart and sly they were and how very , very fond they were of tender young Chucks for dinner . 17 The three little Chucks shivered when they smelled of Reddy 's track , and the hair along their backs stood up in a way that was very funny to see . 18 Then Johnny Chuck took them over to the edge of the old orchard , where they could peep out over the Green Meadows . 19 He pointed out old Whitetail the Marshhawk , sailing back and forth over the meadows , and told them how once , when he was a little Chuck and had run away from home , old Whitetail had nearly caught him . 20 He told them about Farmer Brown 's boy and about Bowser the Hound and a great many other things that little Chucks should learn about . 1 It was a bookmark of perforated cardboard , with a gorgeous red and yellow worsted goblet worked on it , and below , in green letters , the solemn warning , `` Touch Not The Cup . 10 -- we went to Kitty Marr 's party . 11 It was a fine December evening ; the sharp air of morning had mellowed until it was as mild as autumn . 12 There had been no snow , and the long fields , sloping down from the homestead , were brown and mellow . 13 A weird , dreamy stillness had fallen on the purple earth , the dark fir woods , the valley rims , the sere meadows . 14 Nature seemed to have folded satisfied hands to rest , knowing that her long wintry slumber was coming upon her . 15 At first , when the invitations to the party had come , Aunt Janet had said we could not go ; but Uncle Alec interceded in our favour , perhaps influenced thereto by Cecily 's wistful eyes . 16 If Uncle Alec had a favourite among his children it was Cecily , and he had grown even more indulgent towards her of late . 17 Now and then I saw him looking at her intently , and , following his eyes and thought , I had , somehow , seen that Cecily was paler and thinner than she had been in the summer , and that her soft eyes seemed larger , and that over her little face in moments of repose there was a certain languor and weariness that made it very sweet and pathetic . 18 And I heard him tell Aunt Janet that he did not like to see the child getting so much the look of her Aunt Felicity . 19 `` Cecily is perfectly well , '' said Aunt Janet sharply . 20 `` She 's only growing very fast . 1 `` I 've heard the minister say that and it is true . ' 3 So saying , Mohammed gave Neangir four piastres to start him in the great city , and obtained leave for him to join a caravan which was about to set off for Constantinople . 4 The journey took some days , as caravans go very slowly , but at last the walls and towers of the capital appeared in the distance . 5 When the caravan halted the travellers went their different ways , and Neangir was left , feeling very strange and rather lonely . 6 He had plenty of courage and made friends very easily ; still , not only was it the first time he had left the village where he had been brought up , but no one had ever spoken to him of Constantinople , and he did not so much as know the name of a single street or of a creature who lived in it . 7 Wondering what he was to do next , Neangir stood still for a moment to look about him , when suddenly a pleasant-looking man came up , and bowing politely , asked if the youth would do him the honour of staying in his house till he had made some plans for himself . 8 Neangir , not seeing anything else he could do , accepted the stranger 's offer and followed him home . 9 They entered a large room , where a girl of about twelve years old was laying three places at the table . 10 ` Zelida , ' said the stranger , ` was I not quite right when I told you that I should bring back a friend to sup with us ? ' 4 When Antonio had paid his account he went to the stables and took out his donkey , as he thought , and fastening a sack of gravel , which the landlord had substituted for his precious stones , on the creature 's back , he set out for his home . 5 No sooner had he arrived there than he called out : ` Mother , come quickly , and bring table-cloths and sheets with you , and spread them out on the ground , and you will soon see what wonderful treasures I have brought you . ' 8 But this time he met with no success , for the donkey took no more notice of the magic word than he would have done if a lyre had been twanged in his ear . 9 Two , three , and four times did Antonio pronounce ` Bricklebrit , ' but all in vain , and he might as well have spoken to the wind . 10 Disgusted and furious with the poor creature , he seized a thick stick and began to beat it so hard that he nearly broke every bone in its body . 11 The miserable donkey was so distracted at such treatment that , far from pouring out precious stones , it only tore and dirtied all the fine linen . 12 When poor Masella saw her table-cloths and sheets being destroyed , and that instead of becoming rich she had only been made a fool of , she seized another stick and belaboured Antonio so unmercifully with it , that he fled before her , and never stopped till he reached the ogre 's cave . 13 When his master saw the lad returning in such a sorry plight , he understood at once what had happened to him , and making no bones about the matter , he told Antonio what a fool he had been to allow himself to be so imposed upon by the landlord , and to let a worthless animal be palmed off on him instead of his magic donkey . 14 Antonio listened humbly to the ogre 's words , and vowed solemnly that he would never act so foolishly again . 15 And so a year passed , and once more Antonio was overcome by a fit of home-sickness , and felt a great longing to see his own people again . 16 Now the ogre , although he was so hideous to look upon , had a very kind heart , and when he saw how restless and unhappy Antonio was , he at once gave him leave to go home on a visit . 17 At parting he gave him a beautiful table-cloth , and said : ` Give this to your mother ; but see that you do n't lose it as you lost the donkey , and till you are safely in your own house beware of saying `` Table-cloth , open , '' and `` Table-cloth , shut . '' 18 If you do , the misfortune be on your own head , for I have given you fair warning . ' 19 Antonio set out on his journey , but hardly had he got out of sight of the cave than he laid the table-cloth on the ground and said , ` Table-cloth , open . ' 20 In an instant the table-cloth unfolded itself and disclosed a whole mass of precious stones and other treasures . 1 The Circassians could with difficulty be comforted for the loss of the talismans , but Aurora and Argentine entreated them to dry their tears , as their father , Siroco , who was governor of Alexandria , would not fail to reward them in any manner they wished . 2 This promise was soon confirmed by Siroco himself , who came into the garden with the Bassa and his two sons , and was speedily joined by the ladies of the family . 3 Only Hassan was absent . 4 It was the hour in which he was condemned to bewail his ebony hand . 5 To the surprise of all a noise was at this moment heard in a corner of the terrace , and Hassan himself appeared surrounded by slaves , clapping his hands and shouting with joy . soon affairs went badly with them , so they determined to wander away to seek their fortune . 14 In packing up , the sister found a knife which the monk had left for his godson , and this she gave to her brother . 15 Then they went on their way , taking with them the three sheep which were all that remained of their flocks . 16 After wandering for three days they met a man with three dogs who proposed that they should exchange animals , he taking the sheep , and they the dogs . 17 The brother and sister were quite pleased at this arrangement , and after the exchange was made they separated , and went their different ways . 18 Janni and his sister in course of time came to a great castle , in which dwelt forty Draken , who , when they heard that Janni had come , fled forty fathoms underground . 19 So Janni found the castle deserted , and abode there with his sister , and every day went out to hunt with the weapons the Draken had left in the castle . 20 One day , when he was away hunting , one of the Draken came up to get provisions , not knowing that there was anyone in the castle . 1 She passed close to the king , riding at full speed , without taking any notice of him ;
