'' 3 CHAPTER XVIII . 4 SARA RAY HELPS OUT We all missed Aunt Olivia greatly ; she had been so merry and companionable , and had possessed such a knack of understanding small fry . 5 But youth quickly adapts itself to changed conditions ; in a few weeks it seemed as if the Story Girl had always been living at Uncle Alec 's , and as if Uncle Roger had always had a fat , jolly housekeeper with a double chin and little , twinkling blue eyes . 6 I do n't think Aunt Janet ever quite got over missing Aunt Olivia , or looked upon Mrs. Hawkins as anything but a necessary evil ; but life resumed its even tenor on the King farm , broken only by the ripples of excitement over the school concert and letters from Aunt Olivia describing her trip through the land of Evangeline . 7 We incorporated the letters in Our Magazine under the heading `` From Our Special Correspondent '' and were very proud of them . 8 At the end of June our school concert came off and was a great event in our young lives . 9 It was the first appearance of most of us on any platform , and some of us were very nervous . 10 We all had recitations , except Dan , who had refused flatly to take any part and was consequently care-free . 11 `` I 'm sure I shall die when I find myself up on that platform , facing people , '' sighed Sara Ray , as we talked the affair over in Uncle Stephen 's Walk the night before the concert . 12 `` I 'm afraid I 'll faint , '' was Cecily 's more moderate foreboding . 13 `` I 'm not one single bit nervous , '' said Felicity complacently . 14 `` I 'm not nervous this time , '' said the Story Girl , `` but the first time I recited I was . '' 15 `` My Aunt Jane , '' remarked Peter , `` used to say that an old teacher of hers told her that when she was going to recite or speak in public she must just get it firmly into her mind that it was only a lot of cabbage heads she had before her , and she would n't be nervous . '' 16 `` One might n't be nervous , but I do n't think there would be much inspiration in reciting to cabbage heads , '' said the Story Girl decidedly . 17 `` I want to recite to PEOPLE , and see them looking interested and thrilled . '' 18 `` If I can only get through my piece without breaking down I do n't care whether I thrill people or not , '' said Sara Ray . 19 `` I 'm afraid I 'll forget mine and get stuck , '' foreboded Felix . 20 `` Some of you fellows be sure and prompt me if I do -- and do it quick , so 's I wo n't get worse rattled . '' 1 Let me go ! '' 2 yelled Happy Jack , as he backed out of the hollow stump faster than he had gone in , a great deal faster . 3 Can you guess why ? 4 I 'll tell you . 5 It was because he was being pulled out . 6 Yes , Sir , Happy Jack Squirrel was being pulled out by his big , bushy tail . 7 Happy Jack was more frightened than hurt . 8 To be sure , it is not at all comfortable to have one 's tail pulled , but Happy Jack would n't have minded this so much had it not been so unexpected , or if he could have seen who was pulling it . 9 And then , right inside Happy Jack did n't feel a bit good . 10 Why ? 11 Well , because he was doing a dreadful thing , and he knew that it was a dreadful thing . 12 He had broken into somebody 's storehouse to steal . 13 He was sure that it was Striped Chipmunk 's storehouse , and he would n't admit to himself that he was going to steal , actually steal . 14 But all the time , right down deep in his heart , he knew that if he took any of those hickory nuts it would be stealing . 15 But Happy Jack had been careless . 16 When he had made the doorway big enough for him to crawl inside , he had left his tail hanging outside . 17 Some one had very , very softly stolen up and grabbed it and begun to pull . 18 It was so sudden and unexpected that Happy Jack yelled with fright . 19 When he could get his wits together , he thought of course Striped Chipmunk had come back and was pulling his tail . 20 When he thought that , he got over his fright right away , for Striped Chipmunk is such a little fellow that Happy Jack knew that he had nothing ; to fear from him . 1 CHAPTER XX . 2 EXTRACTS FROM `` OUR MAGAZINE '' EDITORIAL As will be seen there is no Honour Roll in this number . 3 Even Felicity has thought all the beautiful thoughts that can be thought and can not think any more . 4 Peter has never got drunk but , under existing circumstances , that is not greatly to his credit . 5 As for our written resolutions they have silently disappeared from our chamber walls and the place that once knew them knows them no more for ever . 6 -LRB- PETER , PERPLEXEDLY : `` Seems to me I 've heard something like that before . '' -RRB- 7 It is very sad but we will all make some new resolutions next year and maybe it will be easier to keep those . 8 THE STORY OF THE LOCKET THAT WAS BAKED This was a story my Aunt Jane told me about her granma when she was a little girl . 9 Its funny to think of baking a locket , but it was n't to eat . 10 She was my great granma but Ill call her granma for short . 11 It happened when she was ten years old . 12 Of course she wasent anybodys granma then . 13 Her father and mother and her were living in a new settlement called Brinsley . 14 Their nearest naybor was a mile away . 15 One day her Aunt Hannah from Charlottetown came and wanted her ma to go visiting with her . 16 At first granma 's ma thought she couldent go because it was baking day and granma 's pa was away . 17 But granma wasent afraid to stay alone and she knew how to bake the bread so she made her ma go and her Aunt Hannah took off the handsome gold locket and chain she was waring round her neck and hung it on granmas and told her she could ware it all day . 18 Granma was awful pleased for she had never had any jewelry . 19 She did all the chores and then was needing the loaves when she looked up and saw a tramp coming in and he was an awful villenus looking tramp . 20 He dident even pass the time of day but just set down on a chair . 1 Now everybody would say , `` What a bold fellow ! '' 2 CHAPTER XXIII SAMMY JAY IS QUITE UPSET I know of nothing sweeter than Success to Squirrel or to man . 3 Happy Jack . 4 Very few people can be all puffed up with pride without showing it . 5 Happy Jack Squirrel could n't . 6 Just to have looked at him you would have known that he was feeling very , very good about something . 7 When he thought no one was looking , he would actually strut . 8 And it was all because he considered himself a very bold fellow . 9 That was a new feeling for Happy Jack . 10 He knew that all his neighbors considered him rather timid , and many a time he had envied , actually envied Jimmy Skunk and Reddy Fox and Unc ' Billy Possum and even Sammy Jay because they did such bold things and had dared to visit Farmer Brown 's dooryard and henhouse in spite of Bowser the Hound . 11 But now he felt that he dared do a thing that not one of them dared do . 12 He dared go right into Farmer Brown 's house and make himself quite at home in the room of Farmer Brown 's boy . 13 He felt that he was a tremendously brave fellow . 14 You see , he quite forgot one thing . 15 He forgot that he had found out that love destroys fear , and that though it might look to others like a very bold thing to walk right into Farmer Brown 's house , it really was n't bold at all , because all the time he knew that no harm would come to him . 16 It is never brave to do a thing that you are not afraid to do . 17 It had been brave of him to go in at that open window the first time , because then he had been afraid , but now he was n't afraid , and so it was no longer either brave or bold of him . 18 Tommy Tit the Chickadee knew all this , and he used to chuckle to himself as he saw how proud of himself Happy Jack was , but he said nothing to any one about it . 19 Of course , it was n't long before others began to notice Happy Jack 's pride . 20 One of the first was Sammy Jay . 1 It was not that he was afraid for himself . 2 Oh , my , no ! 3 Johnny Chuck felt perfectly able to take care of himself . 4 But there was Polly Chuck ! 5 He was terribly afraid that something might happen to Polly Chuck . 6 You see she was not big and strong like him , and then Polly Chuck was apt to be careless . 7 So for a while Johnny Chuck worried a great deal . 8 But Reddy Fox did n't come again in daytime . 9 You see Bowser the Hound had given him such a scare that he did n't dare to . 10 He sometimes came at night and sniffed hungrily at Johnny Chuck 's doorway , but Johnny and Polly were safe inside , and this did n't trouble them a bit . 11 And Farmer Brown 's boy seemed to have forgotten all about the new house . 12 So after a while Johnny Chuck stopped worrying so much . 13 The fact is Johnny Chuck had something else to think about . 14 He had a secret . 15 Yes , Sir , Johnny Chuck had a secret . 16 Sammy Jay came up to the old orchard almost every morning . 17 His sharp eyes were not long in finding out that Johnny Chuck had a secret , but try as he would he could not find out what that secret was . 18 Whatever it was , it made Johnny Chuck very happy . 19 He would come out on his doorstep and smile and sometimes give a funny little whistle of pure joy . 20 It puzzled Sammy Jay a great deal . 1 `` Do you know , Tommy , I 've grown very fond of Farmer Brown 's boy . '' 2 `` Of course . 3 Dee , dee , dee , of course . 4 Everybody who really knows him is fond of him . 5 I 've said all along that he is the best friend we 've got , but no one seemed to believe me . 6 I 'm glad you 've found it out for yourself . 7 I tell you what , I 'll go up to his house and have another look around . '' 8 And without waiting for a reply , Tommy was off as fast as his little wings could take him . 9 `` I hope , I do hope , that nothing has happened to him , '' mumbled Happy Jack , as he pretended to hunt for buried nuts while he waited for Tommy Tit to come back , and by `` him '' he meant Farmer Brown 's boy . 10 CHAPTER XVII TOMMY TIT BRINGS NEWS No one knows too much , but many know too little . 11 Happy Jack . 12 Happy Jack very plainly was not happy . 13 His name was the only happy thing about him . 14 He fussed about on the edge of the Green Forest . 15 He just could n't keep still . 16 When he thought anybody was looking , he pretended to hunt for some of the nuts he had buried in the fall , and dug holes down through the snow . 17 But as soon as he thought that no one was watching , he would scamper up a tree where he could look over to Farmer Brown 's house and look and look . 18 It was very clear that Happy Jack was watching for some one and that he was anxious , very anxious , indeed . 19 It was getting late in the afternoon , and soon the Black Shadows would begin to creep out from the Purple Hills , behind which jolly , round , red Mr. Sun would go to bed . 20 It would be bedtime for Happy Jack then , for you know he goes to bed very early , just as soon as it begins to get dark .
